questions.text: A patient with deep vein thrombosis was started on a new drug. This drug acts by inhibiting the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase. Which of the following drugs is used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Warfarin acts by inhibiting the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase.

Activation of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X and proteins C and S is done by carboxylation of their glutamate residues, with the help of the reduced form of vitamin K as a co-factor. This reduced form of vitamin K needs to be constantly recycled back from its oxidized form for the reaction to continue. This recycling is done by the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase, which is competitively inhibited by warfarin. Hence, there will be a reduction in the activation of coagulation factors.

The image below shows warfarin's mechanism of action.

The half-life of proteins C and S are 8 and 24 hours, respectively, which is relatively shorter than the half-lives of other clotting factors, particularly factor II. Therefore, the full antithrombotic effect of warfarin is not achieved for 4 to 5 days. For this reason, warfarin must be bridged with a rapidly acting parenteral anticoagulant, such as heparin, low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH), or fondaparinux, in patients with thrombosis or at high risk for thrombosis.

Uses of warfarin are acute deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, and preventing stroke or systemic embolization in patients with a mechanical heart valve. 

Adverse effects of warfarin are bleeding, skin necrosis, purple toe syndrome (due to cholesterol microemboli released from atheromatous plaques, which cause arteriolar occlusion), and fetal warfarin syndrome (hypoplasia of the nose, eye socket, hand bones, and growth retardation).

Warfarin is mainly metabolized by the CYP2C9 enzyme. Drugs that affect the CYP2C9 enzyme can alter the anticoagulant function of warfarin and these include the following:

Reduced efficacy:

  • CYP2C9 activation by drugs: barbiturates, carbamazepine, rifampin
  • Oral contraceptives: increase blood levels of clotting factors

Increased efficacy:

  • Drugs causing CYP2C9 inhibition:
    • Amiodarone
    • Azole antifungals
    • Cimetidine
    • Clopidogrel
    • Cotrimoxazole
    • Disulfiram
    • Isoniazid
    • Metronidazole

Other options:
 
Option B: Heparin acts by activating antithrombin III, thereby inactivating the active form of clotting factors II, IX, X, XI, XII, and XIII. Adverse effects are bleeding and heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) due to the formation of antibodies against the heparin-platelet complex.
 
Option C: Dabigatran is a direct thrombin inhibitor. It is used for the prevention of embolism and stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation. Bleeding and dyspepsia are the most important adverse effects.
 
Option D: Rivaroxaban is a direct inhibitor of factor Xa. It is used for prophylaxis and treatment of deep vein thrombosis. Side effects reported are bleeding, nausea, hypotension, tachycardia, and edema.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding indirect ophthalmoscopy?

choices.text: The image produced is erect and real
Condensor needs to be kept very close to the eye

questions.solution:
An indirect ophthalmoscope produces an inverted real image of 3 to 5 times magnification.

Advantages of the binocular indirect ophthalmoscope are:

  • Visualization through hazy media is possible due to strong in built illumination system.
  • Field of view is much larger than direct ophthalmoscopy.
  • Examination of peripheral retina up to ora serrata is possible.
  • Depth perception of the lesion is possible due to stereopsis with binocular indirect ophthalmoscope.
  • Visualization of fundus in very high refractive error is also possible, where it may not be possible to focus the lesion with direct ophthalmoscope.
  • A real, Inverted image is formed (Option A).
  • There is an arms distance between the condensing lens and the patient's eye (Option C).

Other options:

Option D: 15 times magnification is seen with a direct ophthalmoscope.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought with a history of impaired vision. On examination, she has light hair, light skin color, and pale blue iris. The child has a normal IQ.  You suspect a disorder due to a deficiency of an enzyme tyrosinase. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features along with the deficiency of the enzyme tyrosinase point to the diagnosis of albinism.

The first step in melanin synthesis involves the oxidation of L-tyrosine to DOPA by the enzyme tyrosinase. Tyrosinase again acts on DOPA to form dopaquinone, which undergoes a series of reactions to form melanin. Mutations in the tyrosinase gene lead to a complete inability to produce melanin.

Albinism is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. Oculocutaneous albinism (OCA) is characterized by a reduction or complete lack of melanin pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes. This manifests as white hair, white skin, and iris appearing blue-gray in oblique light. Ocular manifestations include photophobia, nystagmus, and decreased visual acuity. The IQ of the child will be normal.

Given below is an image of a young child with albinism showing white hair, skin, and pale iris:

Other options:

Option B: Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency leads to phenylketonuria. This defect results in the impaired conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine. Infants appear normal at birth. They gradually develop hyperactivity, agitation, low IQ, and hypopigmentation (due to tyrosine deficiency), Phenylacetate gives rise to the characteristic mousy odor in the body sweat, and urine.

Option C: The metabolic defect in alkaptonuria is a defective homogentisate oxidase. Patients typically will have dark urine or urine that turns dark on standing, ochronosis(bluish-black pigmentation in connective tissue), arthritis, the pigment in the sclera, and ear cartilage.

Option D: Tyrosinemia type 2 (oculocutaneous type) is caused due to the deficiency of the enzyme tyrosine transaminase. Clinical findings include palmoplantar keratosis, painful corneal erosions with photophobia, and learning disability.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is not true about group discussion?

choices.text: Many different topics are spoken about in one discussion.
A group leader guides the conversation.
It can bring about change in attitude of the participants.
It usually consists of 6 to 12 people.

questions.solution:
A group discussion discusses one topic on its agenda.

Group discussion is an aggregation of people interacting in a face to face manner.

  • Exchange of ideas, knowledge, and opinions is done by participants which influences a change in their attitudes.
  • It usually involves 6–12 people with a group leader who guides the conversation, giving equal opportunity to everyone to voice themselves.
  • In a group discussion, everyone must speak and be open to criticism without interruption of another.
  • Limitation – not everyone is open to speaking in public and possibility of diversion of topic of discussion is high when many people are involved.

questions.text: You read a news alert that mentions a novel drug has received marketing approval for diabetes mellitus and that it has shown positive results in a pivotal trial. This corresponds to which phase of clinical trials?
questions.solution:
Phase III trials are usually considered pivotal trials and are necessary for the approval of the majority of drugs. They are also called multi-site trials and are done for 3–5 years.

When the initial Phase III trials are complete, the sponsor (usually a pharmaceutical company) applies to the FDA for approval to market the drug. This application is called either a New Drug Application (NDA) or a Biologics License Application (BLA).

In some drugs related to rare diseases or malignancies, phase II studies are considered as pivotal, and the drug may be approved on the basis of phase II studies.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Factories Act?

choices.text: Children under 14 years of age must not be employed in factories.
A child of 16 years can be employed in certain industries from 6 AM to 9 PM.
The maximum working hours for an adult is 72 hours per week.
A child of 16 years can work till 6-8 hours per day.

questions.solution:
Factories act prohibits children of < 14 years from being employed.

For children between 14–18 years

  • They can be employed only in certain industries and work between 6 AM–7 PM
  • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.


Hours of work for Adults: Maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day; if overtime is paid, then it should be not more than 60 hrs per week.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

  • The act defines factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 
  • Age of employment –  prohibition children of < 14 years from working.
  • Adolescents between 15 – 18 years
    • Can be employed  only in certain industries and  work between 6 AM – 7 PM
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours
    • They are allowed to take leave once in every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days
  • Hours of work for adults: maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day, if working overtime then it should be no more than 60 hrs per week
  • Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person
  • Safety and Welfare measures:
    • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
    • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
    • > 250 Workers – Canteen
    • > 50 Workers- Crèche*

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law which has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers- 12 weeks to 26 weeks
  • Working mothers, already with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

 

*for fifty women worker after the 1976 amendment.

questions.text: Which amongst the following can be used to treat kesari dal toxicity?
questions.solution:
Vitamin C in doses of 500-1000 mg can be used for the prevention and treatment of lathyrism (kesari dal toxicity).

Lathyrism is a paralyzing disease of humans and animals. It is due to the consumption of khesari dal or Lathyrus sativus. When the husk is removed, it looks similar to red gram or Bengal gram. It is mostly consumed by poor agricultural laborers because it is relatively cheap. Lathyrism is more prevalent in parts of Madhya Pradesh, Uttar Pradesh, Odisha, and Bihar. The Prevention of Food Adulteration Act in India has banned Lathyrus sativus in all forms (whole/ split/ flour). 

In humans, it is referred to as neurolathyrism because it affects the nervous system. It is characterized by gradually developing spastic paralysis of the lower limbs. Beta-oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA) is the toxic compound causing this disease. It is water-soluble and can be removed by the following methods:

  • Soaking pulses in hot water and discarding the water 
  • Overnight soaking in lime water, followed by boiling 
  • Parboiling - for large-scale detoxification

questions.text: Baroreceptor stimulation would result in _______
questions.solution:
Baroreceptor stimulation would result in a decreased sympathetic discharge to the heart.

The baroreceptors are stretch receptors in the walls of the heart and blood vessels. 

Baroreceptor stimulation, by distension of the structures they are located in, inhibits the tonic discharge of sympathetic nerves and excites the vagal innervation of the heart. This leads to:

  • Vasodilation and venodilation
  • Hypotension
  • Bradycardia
  • Decrease in cardiac output

questions.text: A patient with diabetes insipidus is prescribed vasopressin. This drug has its maximum effect on which part of the renal tubule?
questions.solution:
Vasopressin has the maximum effect on the collecting ducts.

Vasopressin acts by inserting aquaporin 2 present in cytoplasmic vesicles of principal cells on to the apical membrane. The effect is mediated via the vasopressin V2 receptor, cyclic adenosine 5-monophosphate (cAMP), and protein kinase A. When vasopressin is absent, the collecting duct epithelium is relatively impermeable to water.

questions.text: A 35 year old male patient presented to the clinic with complaints of  episodic vertigo,  sense of ear pressure and fullness, decreased hearing, and a low-tone roaring tinnitus. What is the possible clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is that of Meniere's disease.

It is also called endolymphatic hydrops.It is commonly seen in patients 35-60 years of age and male patients are more commonly affected than females.

The main pathology in Ménière’s disease is the distension of the endolymphatic system due to the increased volume of endolymph.

Accordingly, the typical history involves episodic attacks of true whirling vertigo, which usually are preceded by a variable sense of ear pressure and fullness, decreased hearing, and low-tone roaring tinnitus. 

Examination:

  • Otoscopy - No abnormality seen in the tympanic membrane.
  • Nystagmus - Seen only during an acute attack. The quick component of nystagmus is towards the unaffected ear.
  • Tuning fork test - Indicate sensorineural hearing loss. Rinne's test is positive, Weber is lateralized to the better ear. Absolute bone conduction is reduced in the affected ear.

 Other options:

Option B: BPPV is not associated with hearing loss.

Option C: Syncope is associated with loss of consciousness.

Option D: Petrositis is not associated with episodic vertigo like in Meniere's disease.

questions.text: Identify the fungus shown in the image given below which is stained by India ink dye.
questions.solution:
The image above shows the fungus cryptococcus.

The image shows India ink preparation which is employed to detect the presence of capsulated yeast, cryptococcus neoformans. It induces negative staining by creating a black, semi-opaque background that makes the capsule of the yeast clearly visible. Cryptococcus has a polysaccharide capsule which is demonstrated as clear halos against a black background.

Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungus that is found worldwide as a saprophyte in soil enriched with pigeon droppings. It may cause infection in immune-competent people, resulting in a flu-like illness with complete recovery.

Infection in immunocompromised people like AIDS patients or patients with hematological malignancies results in meningoencephalitis.

Mucicarmine stain can also be used in the identification of cryptococcus. The image given below shows mucicarmine stained specimen of lung tissue containing cryptococci.

Culture on Sabouraud dextrose agar (SDA) at 37'C appears as smooth, mucoid, and creamy white. The cryptococcal antigen(in serum and CSF) is sensitive and specific and can be demonstrated by the latex agglutination test.

Treatment of cryptococcal meningitis involves a combination therapy of amphotericin B with flucytosine. Fluconazole can be added with these drugs in AIDS patients to prevent relapse.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man is admitted with a history of altered sensorium, abnormal behavior, and hydrophobia. He was bitten by a stray dog 4 weeks ago. The patient subsequently died and on autopsy, the following findings are seen in the pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum. What are these microscopic findings called?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features of altered sensorium, abnormal behavior, and hydrophobia a few weeks after a dog bite are suggestive of rabies. Negri bodies are the pathognomonic microscopic finding in rabies.

Negri bodies are cytoplasmic, round to oval, eosinophilic inclusions that can be found in the pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum, sites that are usually devoid of inflammation.

The rabies virus can be detected within Negri bodies by ultrastructural and immunohistochemical methods.

questions.text: What is the Nalgonda technique used for?

choices.text: Defluoridation of water using lime and alum
Steeping pulses in hot water for toxin removal
Air floatation of grains to remove ergot

questions.solution:
Nalgonda technique is used for defluoridation of water which involves the addition of lime and alum followed by flocculation, sedimentation, and filtration.

Fluorosis occurs when drinking water contains excess amounts of fluorine, in the range of 3-5mg/L. It is endemic in parts of India- Andhra Pradesh (Nellore, Nalgonda, Prakasam), Punjab, Haryana, Karnataka, Kerala, Tamil Nadu. 

Symptoms correspond to levels of fluoride intake:

  • Dental fluorosis: (1.5mg/L) Occurs if excess fluoride is ingested during the period of tooth calcification, i.e. in the first 7 years of life. Best seen on the upper incisors and almost exclusively affects only permanent teeth. It causes mottling on dental enamel, the appearance of chalky-white patches on the teeth, and loss of shine in the early stages. The white spots progressively turn yellow and can even become brown-black. The loss of enamel gives a corroded appearance. 
  • Skeletal fluorosis: (3-6mg/L) Occurs due to the heavy deposition of fluoride in the skeleton. Fluorosis stimulates osteoblastic activity, fluorapatite crystals are laid down in bone and these are usually resistant to secondary osteoclastic resorption. This leads to calcium retention, osteosclerosis, and osteophytosis. Ossification of ligaments and fascial attachments is characteristic.
  • Crippling fluorosis: (>10mg/L) Can lead to permanent disability. 

Genu valgum and osteoporosis of the lower limb are seen in a newer form of fluorosis in Tamil Nadu and Andhra Pradesh. It is seen in people consuming jawar (sorghum), as it promotes greater retention of ingested fluoride.

The given images show dental fluorosis and skeletal fluorosis (interosseous-membrane-calcification), respectively:

 

Interventions for Fluorosis 

  • Change the drinking water source with a lower fluoride content (0.5 to 0.8 mg/L). Running surface water contains lower quantities of fluorides than groundwater sources.
  • The National Environmental Engineering Research Institute, Nagpur developed a technique for removing fluoride by a chemical treatment called the Nalgonda technique. 
  • Fluoride supplements should not be prescribed for children who drink fluoridated water.
  • The use of fluoride toothpaste in areas of endemic fluorosis is not recommended for children up to 6 years of age

Other options:

Superchlorination of water is the addition of large amounts of chlorine to the water, for disinfection. The excess is later removed. It is done for heavily polluted water with fluctuating quality.

Steeping pulses in hot water for toxin removal is done for Lathyrism. The toxin beta oxalyl amino alanine in its crystalline form is water-soluble. The pulse is soaked in boiling water for 2 hours and the water is drained off completely. It is then washed with clean water and dried. 

Air floatation of grains is done to remove ergot, which is a field fungus. It can be removed by floating the grains in 20% saltwater, air floatation, or hand picking.

questions.text: A host in which the larval stage of the parasite remains viable without further development is referred to as ______.
questions.solution:
A host in which the larval stage of the parasite remains viable without further development is referred to as the paratenic host.

 

Types of hosts:

  • Definitive host: in which sexual reproduction of parasite takes place.
  • Intermediate host: in which asexual multiplication of parasite occurs.
  • Paratenic host: in which the larval stage of the parasite remains viable without further development.
  • Reservoir host: a host that harbors the parasite and acts as an important source of infection to other susceptible hosts especially in endemic areas.
  • Accidental host: in which parasite is not usually found.

questions.text: Muscle myosin and actin filaments are kept in place by ______
questions.solution:
The side-by-side relationship between the myosin and actin filaments is maintained by a large number of filamentous molecules of a protein called titin.

Titin is a filamentous and springy protein. These springy titin molecules act as a framework that holds the myosin and actin filaments in place so that the contractile machinery of the sarcomere will work.

One end of the titin molecule is elastic and is attached to the Z disk, acting as a spring and changing length as the sarcomere contracts and relaxes. The other part of the titin molecule tethers it to the myosin thick filament.

APPLIED ASPECT

  • The mutation of genes encoding for titin has been associated with dilated and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

  • The skeletal muscle—associated tibialis muscular dystrophy is a genetic muscle disease of titin that is predicted to destabilize the folded state of the protein.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with a history of diffuse thyroid swelling for the past six months. She also feels that the swelling has increased in size over the last month. Investigations show the TSH levels are elevated. Histopathological examination revealed intense lymphocytic infiltration and Hurthle ​cells as given in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and presence of Hurthle cells is suggestive of Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

In Hashimoto thyroiditis, the thyroid follicles are atrophic and are lined in many areas by Hurthle cells, which are epithelial cells that are distinguished by the presence of abundant eosinophilic, granular cytoplasm (oncocytes). Ultrastructurally, these eosinophilic cells have numerous mitochondria.

This is a metaplastic response of the normally low cuboidal follicular epithelium to ongoing injury.

Image: Histology showing Hurthle cells

Oncocytes can arise in various tissues and are referred to as follows: 

  • Hurthle cells/Askanazy cells (Thyroid gland)
  • Oxyphilic cells (Parotid gland)
  • Apocrine metaplasia (Breast)

questions.text: The level of visceral pleura goes up to which of the following levels during deep inspiration?
questions.solution:
The visceral pleura is adherent to the lung. During deep inspiration, the lung moves into the costodiaphragmatic recess and may reach up to the level between middle and lower one-third of the right surface of the liver, which is marked as 'C' in the given image.

Relations of the right surface of the liver:

  • Upper one-third: It is related to the diaphragm, the parietal pleura, visceral pleura and the lung.
  • Middle one-third: It is related to the diaphragm, cost-diaphragmatic recess.
  • Lower one-third: It is in direct relation to the chest wall.

During quiet respiration, the lungs do not fill the costodiaphragmatic recess, so it reaches up to a level between upper and middle one-third (Level B, as shown in the image). However, during deep inspiration, they move into the costodiaphragmatic recess and reaches up to a level between middle and lower one-third (Level C, as shown in the image).

questions.text: Which of the following drug is used as an antagonist in opioid poisoning?
questions.solution:
Naloxone drug is used as an antagonist in opioid poisoning.

Naloxone is a competitive pure opioid antagonist which reverses all effects of an opioid overdose except sedation. It is a pan antagonist with an affinity for all known opioid receptors. It stimulates the release of prolactin in women.

Opioid-induced respiratory depression is mediated by the action of µ receptors (µ2) in the brainstem respiratory centres. Naloxone is an opioid antagonist, which can reverse the respiratory depression induced by opioids.

Opioid Overdose:

Symptoms:

  • Triad of coma, respiratory depression, and pinpoint pupils(miosis)
  • Hypotension
  • Bradycardia
  • Shallow breathing
  • Hypothermia

Characteristics of opioid toxicity:

  • Opioid intoxication toxidrome - respiratory and mental status depression, analgesia, miosis, orthostatic hypotension, nausea and vomiting, histamine release resulting in localized urticaria and bronchospasm, ileus secondary to decreased GI motility, and urinary retention secondary to increased vesical sphincter tone.
  • Miosis is not universally present from intoxication with every opioid; normal or even enlarged pupils have been documented secondary to diphenoxylate, meperidine, morphine, pentazocine, and propoxyphene toxicity.
  • Opioid-induced acute lung injury, previously known as non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema, is an uncommon complication associated with heroin overdose.

Airway protection and ventilatory maintenance are the most important treatment steps for opioid intoxications, because respiratory depression is the major morbidity and the cause of essentially all the mortality.

  • After adequate ventilation is ensured, administer naloxone.
  • Single-dose activated charcoal can be administered in case opioid ingestion occured within one hour. 

Opioid withdrawal symptoms (mnemonic- O MY WITHDRAWALS):

  • Mydriasis
  • Yawning
  • Weakness
  • Insomnia, irritability
  • Tremors, tachycardia
  • Hyperthermia, hypertension
  • Diarrhoea
  • Rhinorrhoea
  • Apnoeic attacks
  • Weight loss
  • Anxiety
  • Lacrimation
  • Sweating

 

Related Pearl: Pure opioid antagonists

Naloxone: A short-acting opioid antagonist with a duration of action of 1-2 hours. Used in opioid overdose and respiratory depression in newborn due to perinatal opioid use.

Naltrexone: A Long-acting opioid antagonist with a with effects lasting till 48 hours. Used for prevention of relapse in opioid addiction treatment. It is associated with hepatotoxicity. It does not suppress craving in opioid addiction but suppresses craving in chronic alcoholics.

Nalmefene: A Long-acting opioid antagonist with a half-life of 8-10 hours administered intravenously. Used in opioid overdose like naloxone.

questions.text: The given image is a dissected specimen of the posterior surface of the knee. What is the nature of the gait associated with damage to the structure marked in the image below?
questions.solution:
The structure marked is the common peroneal nerve. Damage to it would result in a high stepping gait.

The common peroneal nerve descends down obliquely along the lateral side of the popliteal fossa, until the fibular head. It lies medial to the biceps femoris. The common peroneal nerve is a component of the sciatic nerve. In the posterior thigh, it supplies the short head of the biceps femoris. It curves around the neck of the fibula deep to the peroneus longus and divides into superficial and deep peroneal nerves.

  • The superficial peroneal nerve innervates peroneus longus and peroneus brevis, which are the evertors of the foot, and to the skin over the dorsal area of the foot, except for the first webspace and lateral side of the little toe.
  • The deep peroneal nerve innervates all muscles of the anterior compartment, which are the dorsiflexors of the foot, extensor digitorum brevis, first two dorsal interossei muscles, and skin between the great and second toes.

Common peroneal nerve is more prone to injury as it lies superficial at the level of the lateral aspect of the neck of the fibula. The clinical features of common peroneal nerve injury include the following:

  • Foot drop (image below shows a foot drop in the right calf) leading to high stepping gait.
  • Weakness or paralysis of ankle dorsiflexion, toe extension, and eversion
  • A diminished sensation on the dorsum of the foot including the first dorsal web space
  • Plantar flexion, inversion, and ankle reflex are preserved

Other options:

  • Cautious gait is seen in persons with spinal TB; they will walk carefully with short steps to avoid pain resulting from movement.
  • Wide-stepping gait is a broad-based unstable gait and is indicative of cerebellar dysfunction.
  • Waddling gait is seen in developmental dysplasia of the hip and in proximal muscle weakness.

questions.text: Folate trap occurs due to the deficiency of ______
questions.solution:
Folate trap occurs in the deficiency of Vitamin B12.

The conversion of 5,10-methylene-THF into 5-methyl-THF(methyltetrahydrofolate) is an irreversible process. The major source of tetrahydrofolate for tissues is 5-methyl-THF. The only way to make further use of 5-methyl-THF and to maintain the folate cycle is by the vitamin B12-dependent remethylation of homocysteine to methionine by methionine synthase enzyme.

Decreased activity of methionine synthase in vitamin B12 deficiency results in the accumulation of methyltetrahydrofolate that cannot be used, resulting in a folate trap.

Folate cycle provides a link between the functions of folate and vitamin B12, where vitamin B12 deficiency causes a functional deficiency of folate.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman was brought by her son, during a cataract outreach camp.  She gives a history of trauma to her left eye, one year back and a complete loss of vision in that eye since then. Her left eye image is given below. What is the next line of management ?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette and image showing a dense white opacity, and scarring of more than half of the stroma is characteristic of leucomatous corneal opacity and the treatment of choice is keratoplasty.

Corneal opacities can be graded, depending on their density, as:

  • Nebular corneal opacities or nebula, where only slight opacification of the cornea occurs due to scarring. It is possible to observe the iris clearly through this type of opacity.
  • Macular corneal opacities or macula, which is described as a semi-dense opacity that can be seen with proper illumination. This occurs subsequent to scarring that spans about half the corneal stroma. The iris and pupillary margins are usually visible.
  • Leucomatous corneal opacities or leucoma simplex, which is a white scar that is easily seen just by looking at the eye. It occurs due to scarring of more than half of the corneal stroma.
  • Adherent leucoma is observed when there is perforation and subsequent healing of the cornea, but with the incarceration of the iris in it.

Secondary changes in corneal opacity which may be seen in long-standing cases include hyaline degeneration, calcareous degeneration, pigmentation and atheromatous ulceration.

The treatment depends upon the type of opacity. Keratoplasty is the treatment of choice in leucomatous corneal opacities. Optical iridectomy may be performed in cases with central adherent leucomas. Phototherapeutic keratectomy (PTK) performed with excimer laser is useful only in superficial (nebular) corneal opacities.

Corneal tattooing is a treatment option in patients with corneal opacities with firm scarring and poor vision. It only improves cosmetic appearance.

Related Pearl: Corneal Opacities

Corneal opacity is formed when Bowman's layer (+/- deeper layer) is damaged.

Nebular opacity

  • Faint white
  • Only Bowman's layer is involved
  • Causes more visual handicap than macular opacity due to the scattering of light

Macular opacity

  • White in color
  • Bowman's layer + Half of stromal thickness involved

Leucoma

  • White and opaque
  • BM + half or more than half stromal thickness involved

Image: Leucomatous corneal opacity

questions.text: A 73-year-old woman presents with chronic fatigue and easy bruising. She has had surgery for ovarian cancer 7 years ago along with chemoradiation. Her lab reports reveal pancytopenia and bone marrow biopsy shows the following finding. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of therapy-related myelodysplastic syndrome (t-MDS).

The bone marrow biopsy stained with Perl's Prussian blue shows ringed sideroblasts. They are erythroblasts with iron-laden mitochondria visible as perinuclear granules as shown in the image below.

Myelodysplastic syndrome is a group of clonal stem cell disorders characterized by maturation defects, associated with ineffective hematopoiesis.

It is of two types:

  • Primary MDS - develops slowly, usually after 50 years of age.
  • Secondary or therapy-related MDS (t-MDS) - develops 2 to 8 years after toxic drug or radiation exposure with poor prognosis

Patients usually present with weakness, infections and hemorrhages due to pancytopenia. Both types of MDS have a high risk of transformation to acute myeloid leukemia (AML). However, most frequent and rapid transformation occurs in therapy-related MDS (t-MDS).

VEXAS syndrome (vacuoles, E1 enzyme, X-linked, autoinflammatory, somatic) is a Novel disorder discovered in 2020. It is an adult-onset inflammatory disease with clinical features that bridge rheumatologic & hematologic conditions. VEXAS may be a prototype for new class of “hematoinflammatory diseases.” These diseases would be defined by somatic mutations in hematopoietic cells, systemic inflammation, & potential to evolve into overt myelodysplastic, myeloproliferative, or lymphoproliferative disease.

questions.text: A boxer is wheeled into the ER with complaints of double vision after suffering a severe blow to his face during a match. On examination, there is a flattening of malar prominence, trismus and a step deformity of the infraorbital margin. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of diplopia, flat malar prominence, trismus, and step deformity in the infraorbital margin is suggestive of fracture of zygoma or tripod fracture.

Zygoma is the second most frequently fractured bone in the face. The zygoma fracture is separated at its three processes - the zygomaticofrontal suture, infraorbital margin, and the zygomaticotemporal suture. It has the following clinical features:

  • Flattening of malar prominence. 
  • Trismus, due to depression of zygoma on the underlying coronoid process. 
  • Anesthesia in the distribution of the infraorbital nerve. 
  • Step deformity of infraorbital margin.
  • Oblique palpebral fissure, due to the displacement of lateral palpebral ligament. 
  • Restricted ocular movements, due to entrapment of inferior rectus muscle. It may cause diplopia. 
  • Periorbital emphysema, due to escape of air from the maxillary sinus on nose blowing.

questions.text: There is an outbreak of buboes in the community. What is the vector responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The vector for bubonic plague is Xenopsylla cheopis. It is also called a rat flea. It also transmits murine typhus, chiggerosis, and hymenolepsis diminuta. It can be identified by the presence of a conical-shaped head, the presence of thorax, abdomen, and three pairs of legs. 

Plague is a zoonotic disease caused by Yersinia pestis. It is a gram-negative, non-motile, coccobacillus that exhibits bipolar staining with special stains like Wayson's stain. The reservoir of infections is wild rodents like field mice, gerbils, skunks, etc. In India, Tatera indica is the main reservoir. The important vector of plague is rat flea, also called Xenopsylla cheopis.

Humans acquire the disease by the bite of an infected flea, by direct contact with the tissues of the infected animal, or by droplet infection from cases of pneumonic plague. 

Human plague mainly presents as:

Bubonic plague- This is the most common type of disease. The patient develops a sudden fever, chills, headache, and painful lymphadenitis. Within a few days, the lymph nodes in the groin, axilla, or neck enlarge and are called buboes. This is followed by the suppuration of the buboes. Bubonic plague cannot spread from person to person as the bacilli are locked up in the buboes and do not find a way or easy exit.

Pneumonic plague- It develops as a complication of bubonic-septicemic plague. 

Septicemic plague- It occurs when the infection spreads to blood.

Other options

Option B- Species Phlebotomus argentipes, belongs to the group of sand fly. It transmits kala azar. Diseases caused by other species of sand flies are sandfly fever and oriental sore.

Below image shows sand fly

Option C- Ixodes ticks (hard ticks) transmit rocky mountain spotted fever, Russian spring-summer encephalitis, Colorado tick fever, tularemia, tick paralysis and human babesiosis.

Below image shows Ixodes tick

Option D- Female Anopheles mosquitoes are vectors for malaria and filariasis (not in India). They can be identified by the presence of spotted wings. When resting on a surface, they make an angle with the surface.

The below image shows anopheles mosquito.

Related Pearl: Rat Fleas

  • Rat fleas (Xenopsylla cheopis) belong to the genus Xenopsylla.
  • Their morphology includes a conical head, absent neck, a thorax with 3 segments, and an abdomen with 10 segments. They have three pairs of legs and no wings.
  • The four stages in their life cycle are egg, larva, pupa, and adult.
  • They cannot fly but can leap up to 6 inches horizontally.
  • They transmit diseases by biting, mechanical transmission, and feces.
  • Flea indices that are used in flea surveys are the general flea index, specific flea index, percentage incidence of flea species, and rodent infestation rate.
  • Rat fleas are vectors for endemic typhus (murine typhus), chiggerosis, bubonic plague, and Hymenolepis diminuta.
  • Insecticidal control is mainly by 10% DDT.
  • Resistance to DDT, gamma-HCH, and dieldrin has been recorded.
  • Repellants like diethyltoluamide and benzyl benzoate are efficient.
  • Rodent control also aims to reduce flea infestation.

questions.text: Segawa syndrome is due to the deficiency of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Segawa syndrome (Dopamine-responsive dystonia) is a hereditary progressive dystonia due to the deficiency of tetrahydrobiopterin(BH4). 

It is due to defective GTP cyclohydrolase I enzyme required for BH4 synthesis.

questions.text: A worried mother brings her 18-month-old son to the outpatient department with complaints of repeated urinary tract infections. During diagnostic work-up, pelvic USG shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the USG showing the key-hole sign is suggestive of the posterior urethral valve (PUV). It is seen due to dilatation of the bladder and the proximal urethra.

The posterior urethral valves are membranes that have a small posterior slit, which lies just distal to the verumontanum. They function as flap valves and are obstructive to antegrade urinary flow.

The posterior urethral valve is the most common congenital cause of bladder outlet obstruction in males. PUV is classified into three types based on Young's classification.

Diagnosis is made antenatally with ultrasound, which demonstrates bilateral hydronephrosis above a distended bladder. If the diagnosis is not made antenatally, then neonates typically present with recurrent urinary infections or uremia and renal failure. 

The investigation of choice for a posterior urethral valve is micturating cystourethrography (MCUG).

Initially, the obstruction is relieved by catheterization to preserve renal function. Definitive treatment is by urethroscopic destruction of the valves with lifelong supportive treatment.

questions.text: A patient has lost sensation over the dorsum of the foot and medial 4 toes. There is associated difficulty of eversion of the foot.  Which nerve injury is likely to be the reason for this?
questions.solution:
Loss of sensation/paresthesia/numbness in the dorsum of the foot along with loss of eversion of the foot is due to injury to the superficial peroneal nerve.

The Peroneus longus (principle evertor of the foot) in the lateral compartmentof the leg, is innervated by the superficial peroneal nerve. Damage to the superficial peroneal nerve would result in loss of eversion at the sub-talar joint. 

The lateral compartment of the leg is supplied by the superficial peroneal nerve. It consists of peroneus longus and peroneus brevis.

Other options:

  • Foot drop occurs due to common peroneal nerve injury and sensory loss would involve the front and outer half of the leg and the whole dorsum of the foot. A high stepping gait is seen in this nerve injury.
  • The posterior tibial nerve will involve loss of sensation over the sole of the foot. This is also the nerve involved in tarsal tunnel syndrome.
  • The deep peroneal nerve innervates all muscles of the anterior compartment which are the dorsiflexors of the foot, extensor digitorum brevis, first two dorsal interossei muscles, and skin between great and second toes.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male patient with a history of smoking presented with a painless palpable mass in the parotid region. The biopsy of the mass is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical presentation and histopathological slide showing epithelial elements with lymphoid infiltration are suggestive of a Warthin tumor (papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum) of the parotid gland.

Warthin tumor is the second most common salivary gland neoplasm. It is seen in elderly male smokers. It is a benign, well-encapsulated cystic tumor.

The gross appearance of these tumors shows round to oval encapsulated masses, easily palpable in the superficial parotid. Transection reveals a pale grey surface punctuated by cleft-like spaces filled with mucinous or serous secretions.

Histologically, the tumor shows epithelial and lymphoid elements. The epithelium typically consists of a double layer of oncocytic epithelial cells, with an inner columnar layer and an outer cuboidal layer.

Other options:

Option A: Adenoid cystic carcinoma is poorly encapsulated infiltrative carcinoma involving minor salivary glands, commonly the palatine glands. Histology shows tumor cells, organized in a cribriform growth pattern, resembling swiss cheese. The image is shown below.

Option C: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of the salivary gland, commonly affecting the parotid gland. Many are associated with a balanced (11;19) (q21;p13) chromosomal translocation. Histology shows mucinous, intermediate, and squamous elements, with small to large mucus-filled vacuoles. Image is shown below.

Option D: Pleomorphic adenomas are the most common salivary gland neoplasms. The parotid gland is most commonly involved. They are benign tumors that consist of a mixture of ductal (epithelial), myoepithelial, and mesenchymal cells. Image is shown below.

  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland

questions.solution:
Heart failure cells are hemosiderin-laden macrophages. They are telltale signs of previous episodes of pulmonary edema.

In cardiac failure, red cells and plasma proteins extravasate into the edema fluid within the alveolar spaces. These are then phagocytosed and digested by macrophages. The iron recovered from haemoglobin is stored in the form of hemosiderin.

questions.text: An 18-month-old child was brought to the clinic with a history of fever, cough, and cold. On examination, respiratory rate was 46/min. Which is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Administer IV antibiotics and refer to higher centre
Administer oral antibiotics, warn of danger signs, and send home

questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this child is pneumonia. The most appropriate management would be to start oral antibiotics, parents warned of danger signs and sent home.

Children with symptoms of fever, cough, cold, fast breathing, chest indrawing, and no danger signs are termed to have pneumonia. These children can be managed conservatively with oral antibiotics such as amoxicillin for 5 days. Fast breathing is defined as the respiratory rate of:

  • ≥ 50/min in 2 months to 1 year
  • ≥ 40/min in >1–5 years
  • ≥ 30/min >5 years

The danger signs are listed below:

  • Not able to drink
  • Persistent vomiting
  • Convulsions, lethargic or unconscious
  • Stridor in a calm child
  • Severe malnutrition

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presented with complaints of blood in his urine.  Urine analysis was positive for proteins and red cell casts.  A renal biopsy was done as shown below. Immunofluorescence microscopy revealed granular deposits of C3 on either side of the glomerular basement membrane but was negative for IgG,  C1q, and C4. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, immunofluorescence findings, and the image showing proliferating mesangial cells and capillary endothelial cells are suggestive of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis type 2 (MPGN type 2) or dense-deposit disease. 

The following image shows bright deposits scattered along capillary walls and in the mesangium by immunofluorescence microscopy with antibodies to C3.

This condition belongs to a group of disorders called C3 glomerulopathies and primarily affects children and young adults. It is associated with a dysregulation in the alternative complement pathway. It is clinically and morphologically similar to MPGN type 1 but pathogenetically distinct from it.

In this condition, a circulating autoantibody called C3 nephritic factor is present, which stabilizes the C3 convertase enzyme. The stabilized C3 convertase enhances C3 activation and consumption causing hypocomplementemia. Patients will have consistently decreased serum C3 levels, but normal C1 and C4 levels.

The prognosis is poor, with about half of these patients progressing to end-stage renal disease (ESRD).

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with excessive weight gain, easy bruising, striae, and glucose intolerance. After appropriate workup, she is diagnosed with an adrenocortical adenoma. Which of the following layers of the adrenal gland are involved in this disease?
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation—excessive weight gain, easy bruising, striae, glucose intolerance, and the diagnosis of an adrenocortical adenoma—is consistent with Cushing syndrome caused by excess production of cortisol. The zona fasciculata layer is primarily involved in this condition as it secretes glucocorticoids like cortisol and corticosterone.

Cushing's syndrome is caused by elevated glucocorticoid (cortisol) production. It can be endogenous (intrinsic hormone production) or exogenous (consumption of excessive glucocorticoids). The endogenous causes can also be classified as adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) dependent or independent. 

ACTH is released by the anterior pituitary in response to corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) released by the hypothalamus. It signals the zona fasciculata of the adrenal gland to produce more glucocorticoids by a feedback mechanism. In some instances, ectopic production of cortisol is unresponsive to ACTH released by the pituitary gland. Thus, hypercortisolism can be ACTH-dependent or independent. 

  • 60-70% of cases of endogenous hypercortisolism are caused by ACTH-secreting pituitary adenomas.
  • 5-10% of ACTH secretion is by ectopic tumors, most commonly being small-cell carcinoma of the lung. 

The most common cause of ACTH-independent Cushing's syndrome is primary adrenal neoplasm as seen in this case. 

Clinical features include:

  • Obesity, moon facies, and accumulation of fat in the posterior neck and back (buffalo hump)
  • Decreased muscle mass and proximal limb weakness
  • Hyperglycemia, glucosuria, and polydipsia (secondary diabetes)
  • The skin is thin, fragile, and easily bruised; wound healing is poor, and cutaneous striae are particularly common in the abdominal area.
  • Development of osteoporosis and increased susceptibility to fractures
  • Increased susceptibility to a variety of infections
  • Hypertension
  • Several mental disturbances, including mood swings, depression, and frank psychosis,

questions.text: Identify the drugs marked as A, B, and C.

choices.text: A - Aspirin, B - Eptifibatide, C - Vorapaxar
A - Aspirin, B - Eptifibatide, C - Prasugrel
A - Aspirin, B - Prasugrel, C - Eptifibatide

questions.solution:
The drugs marked A, B and C are aspirin, eptifibatide, and vorapaxar, respectively.

Aspirin causes inhibition of cyclooxygenase-1 (COX-1), which would inhibit the formation of thromboxane A2. Thromboxane A2 is an inducer of platelet aggregation and is a potent vasoconstrictor. Hence, inhibition of its formation is responsible for antiplatelet action.

Aspirin is a non-competitive, irreversible inhibitor of the cyclooxygenase (COX) enzyme. It is a nonselective COX inhibitor and inhibits both COX-1 and COX-2. 

Abciximab, tirofiban, and eptifibatide act by blocking Gp IIb/IIIa receptors. They are mainly used during percutaneous coronary intervention for acute coronary syndrome. They carry a high risk of bleeding and can cause thrombocytopenia.

Vorapaxar primarily inhibits platelet aggregation caused by thrombin. PAR-1 activation by thrombin contributes to platelet aggregation. Vorapaxar is a competitive antagonist of protease-activated receptor-1 (PAR-1). Vorapaxar is indicated in combination with aspirin and/or clopidogrel to reduce thromboembolic events in patients with MI or peripheral vascular disease.

Prasugrel is an irreversible P2Y12 inhibitor and lasts for the entire lifetime of a platelet.

Prasugrel is a prodrug that is used in patients with acute coronary syndrome who have undergone percutaneous coronary intervention. It reduces the rate of thrombotic cardiovascular events in such patients.

questions.text: A 9-month-old baby was brought with complaints of loose stools for 2 weeks. Which of the following organisms is likely to cause this disease?
questions.solution:
Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) causes infantile bacterial diarrhea. It is nontoxigenic and noninvasive.

E. coli is the second most common cause of diarrhea in the pediatric age group. Rotavirus is the most common cause. EPEC causes persistent watery diarrhea which is self-limiting.

EPEC adheres to the mucosal cells of the small bowel and causes loss of microvilli (effacement). This leads to formation of filamentous actin pedestals or cuplike structures and occasionally may cause entry of the EPEC into the mucosal cells.

Pathogenicity requires the presence of two important factors:

  •  Bundle forming pilus encoded by plasmid containing EPEC adherence factor (EAF).
  •  Chromosomal locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE) pathogenecity island.

Other options:

Option B: Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC) produce two potent toxins, verocytotoxin (VT) or Shiga-like toxin (SLT). Especially in young children and the elderly, they cause diarrhea ranging from mild to fatal hemorrhagic colitis and hemorrhagic uremic syndrome (HUS). EHEC primarily targets vascular endothelial cells leading to HUS. E.coli serotype 0157: H7 is associated with EHEC diarrhea and its complications.

Option C: Enterotoxigenic E. coli causes endemic diarrhoea in developing countries and travellers diarrhoea. ETEC serotypes responsible for diarrhea are mostly 06, 08, 015, 025, 027, 0167. It attaches to intestinal mucosa with fimbriae called colonization factor antigens. The pathology is due to the heat-labile toxin (LT) produced by some and heat-stable toxin (ST) produced by others.

Option D: Enteroinvasive E.coli (EIEC) has clinical features are similar to shigellosis. It produces disease by invading the intestinal mucosa.

questions.text: A 21-year-old student presents with ocular redness, foreign body sensation, and excessive tearing following the use of a contact lens. An interface contrast microscopy from his corneal scraping is shown below. What would be the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the demonstration of polygonal cysts in interface contrast microscopy are suggestive of amoebic keratitis caused by acanthamoeba.

Acanthamoeba culbertsoni is an opportunistic protozoan pathogen. It exists as trophozoite form and resistant cystic form. Both these forms are infective. The trophozoite is large and characterized by spine-like pseudopodia (acanthopodia).

Human beings acquire the infection by inhalation of cysts or trophozoites, directly through traumatized skin or eyes, or ingestion of cysts.

It chiefly presents as two chronic conditions:

  • Acanthamoeba keratitis
  • Granulomatous amoebic encephalitis

Acanthamoeba keratitis is an infection of the eyes that typically develops from the entry of the amebic cyst through abrasions on the cornea. Most of the cases are associated with the use of contact lenses. 

Patients usually present with photophobia, excessive tearing, redness, and foreign body sensation and it can be bilateral in contact lens users.

Diagnosis of amoebic keratitis is made by the demonstration of the cyst in corneal scrapings by wet mount, histology, and culture. The cysts are smaller (12-25 micrometer) and polygonal or star-shaped.

Topical administration of biguanides or chlorhexidine with or without diamidine agents can be used for the management of acanthamoeba keratitis. In severe cases penetrating keratoplasty can be done.

The below image shows the ring lesion seen in acanthamoeba keratitis.

 

 

The below image shows cysts of acanthamoeba in lactophenol cotton blue staining.

Other options:

Option B- Naegleria fowleri causes a brain infection, primary amebic meningoencephalitis that leads to brain tissue destruction. Their cysts are spherical and have a smooth double wall. 

Option C- Entamoeba histolytica causes intestinal and extraintestinal amebiasis. Their cysts are spherical in shape. A mature quadrinucleate cyst is the infective form.  An amebic ulcer is a typical lesion seen in intestinal amebiasis which is a flask-shaped ulcer in cross-section. Amebic liver abscess is extraintestinal amebiasis which has a center of abscess that contains thick colored brown pus termed anchovy sauce pus.

Option D- Balamuthia mandrillaris is a free-living ameba that causes granulomatous amebic encephalitis. Their cyst is usually spherical and surrounded by a three-layered cyst wall.

questions.text: A 52 year old woman presents to the ENT surgeon with a history of vertigo whenever she moves sideways on the bed while lying supine. She is nauseous and feels as if the room is spinning.  Altough the symptoms subside after a few minutes, they return when she moves her head. Which of the following is most appropriate to manage her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). The therapeutic maneuver is Epley's maneuver.

BPPV is one of the common causes of recurrent vertigo, and the episodes are brief (<1min) and are always provoked by changes in head position. The attacks are caused by free-floating calcium carbonate crystals usually dislodged from the posterior canal.

A patient presenting with vertigo should be evaluated for ruling out the central lesions (like a tumor in the fourth ventricle, multiple sclerosis, etc) before confirming the diagnosis of BPPV. The Dix-Hallpike maneuver helps rule out central lesions and also diagnose BPPV.

The therapeutic maneuver is Epley's maneuver.

Epley's maneuver:

Other options:

Option A: The diagnostic manoeuvre used in BPPV is the Dix-Hallpike maneuver, the gold standard for diagnosing BPPV.

Dix-Hallpike maneuver:

  1. The maneuver starts with the patient in a sitting position.
  2. Their head is turned 45 degrees towards the ear to be tested.
  3. The examiner quickly brings the patient to a supine position with their head 30 degrees below the horizontal.
  4. The 45-degree head rotation is maintained during the procedure.
  5. Now the examiner observes the patient for nystagmus.

Option B: Glycerol test provides information on the cochlear response to the osmotic changes produced by glycerol in the inner ear. It is used in Meneire's disease.

Option C: Calorie test is a test that uses differences in temperature to diagnose damage to the acoustic nerve. This is the nerve that is involved in hearing and balance. The test also checks for damage to the brain stem.

questions.text: An observer notes that the maternal deaths that happened in hospital deliveries in the past year are higher than maternal deaths in home deliveries. He concludes that homes are a safer place for delivery than hospitals. This is an example of :
questions.solution:
The given association is an association that appears due to improper comparison. It may lead to a spurious association or an association when none actually existed.

Here, maternal mortality is likely to have been higher in-hospital deliveries compared to home deliveries because hospitals attract women at high risk for delivery because of their special equipment and expertise, whereas this is not necessarily the case with home deliveries. When confounding factors and selection biases are not accounted for, it may result in incorrect conclusions regarding the association. So the conclusion that homes are a safer place for delivery than hospitals is likely to have been spurious or artifactual.

The association can be broadly grouped under three headings:

  • Spurious association
  • Indirect association
  • Direct (causal) association
    • One-to-one causal association
    • Multifactorial causation

Other options:

Option A: Direct (causal) association- Two variables are stated to be causally related (AB) if a change in A is followed by a change in B. When factor A is present, disease B must result. Measles is one such disease in which such a relation exists.

Option B: Indirect association- The indirect association is an association between a variable and disease due to the presence of another factor, known or unknown, that is also known as the "confounding" variable. 

Option D: Multifactorial causation is seen in non-communicable diseases or conditions (e.g., Coronary heart disease) where the etiology is multifactorial.

questions.text: Identify the layer marked as '?' in the histopathological image given below:
questions.solution:
The layer marked in the image is the ganglion cell layer.

The retina is composed of 10 microscopic layers and is arranged as 2 distinctive components - pigment epithelium and neurosensory retina. They are as follows:

  1. Retinal pigment epithelium is the outermost layer that is attached to the underlying choroid. It provides metabolic support to the neurosensory retina and acts as an antireflective layer. 
  2. Layers of rods and cones contain the outer segments of the photoreceptors cells. (rods and cones).
  3. External limiting membrane is a fenestrated membrane through which the processes of the rods and cones pass.
  4. Outer nuclear layer consists of the nuclei of rods and cones.
  5. Outer plexiform layer contains connections between the photoreceptor cells to the dendrites of bipolar and horizontal cells.
  6. Inner nuclear layer contains the cell bodies of bipolar, horizontal, and Muller's cells.
  7. Inner plexiform layer contains connections between bipolar cells and dendrites of ganglion cells.
  8. Ganglion cell layer contains ganglion cell bodies.
  9. Nerve fiber layer contains ganglion cell axons that pass through lamina cribrosa to form the optic nerve. 
  10. Internal limiting membrane is the innermost layer and separates the retina from the vitreous.

Related Pearl: Layers of Retina

  • Rods and cones
  • External limiting membrane
  • Outer nuclear layer
  • Outer plexiform layer
  • Inner nuclear layer
  • Inner plexiform layer

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of complicated cataracts?
questions.solution:
Krukenberg spindle is not a feature of complicated cataracts. The slit lamp examination in pigmentary glaucoma shows a pattern of pigment deposition on the back of the cornea-endothelium called Krukenberg spindles. 

Complicated or secondary cataracts develop secondary to inflammatory/degenerative conditions of the lens or other parts of the eye like iridocyclitis and ciliary body tumors which lead to disturbances in the nutrition of the lens. These cataracts present with a breadcrumb appearance and polychromatic luster. 

Even in the early stages, vision is impaired. Inflammation of the posterior segment leads to the characteristic posterior subcapsular cataract while the anterior segment inflammation causes opacification throughout the cortex.

questions.text: A child aged 10 years presented with perianal pruritus which is worse in night. Routine stool examination didn't reveal parasite cysts or eggs. The scotch tape method is done to recover eggs which are non-bile stained. Identify the organism causing the infection.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the scotch tape method to collect perianal egg deposition by (Enterobius vermicularis) is  suggestive of infestation with Pinworm 

Characteristics of Pinworm egg:

  • It is colorless, non-bile stained.
  • It floats in the saturated salt solution.
  • The egg is planoconvex. Eggshell is double layered and relatively thick, though transparent.

Since pinworms are not released in feces, the diagnosis cannot be made by conventional fecal ova and parasite tests. NIH swab method and Scotch tape method are used for the collection of specimens.

Scotch tape method involves:

  1. Take a clear cellophane tape almost 4 cm long
  2. Hold it in such a way(or make a loop) so that sticky surface faces upwards or towards the perianal skin.
  3. Place the sticky surface of tap in the perianal area momentarily
  4. Place the sticky surface down on the glass slide. Examine under microscope.

 

Other eggs that can be collected by scotch tape method are Taenia solium, Taenia saginata and Schistosoma mansoni. Which are none of the options in question

Other eggs which are non-bile stained can be remembered as NEHA - Necator americanus, Enterobius vermicularis, Hymenolepsis nana, Ancylostoma duodenale.

questions.text: X-ray of a 10-year-old boy with fever, drooling of saliva and inspiratory stridor is shown below. The most likely diagnosis is __________
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is acute epiglottitis. The symptoms of drooling of saliva, inspiratory stridor and fever are suggestive of epiglottitis. The lateral X-ray of neck shows enlarged and edematous epiglottis or “thumb” sign.

Retropharyngeal and parapharyngeal abscess present with neck stiffness, trismus and muffled voice while barking cough and hoarseness are seen in tracheolaryngobronchitis (croup).

Retropharyngeal abscess would show widened pre-vertebral space on X-ray whereas croup is characterized by steeple sign. Parapharyngeal abscess is poorly defined on X ray and is best diagnosed on CT.

Acute epiglottitis

  • Microbiology: Streptococcus > Hemophilus influenzae b
  • Median age: 6-12 years
  • Cinical features: Distress (Inspiratory stidor, tripod positioning), Dysphagia and Drooling
  • X ray findings: Thumb sign (enlarged epiglottis), loss of vallecular space
  • Management: Antibiotics, emergency endotracheal intubation as required

Acute laryngotracheobronchitis (Croup)

  • Microbiology: viral infection
  • Median age: 6 months to 6 years
  • Clinical features: barking cough, inspiratory stridor, hoarseness, low grade fever
  • X-ray findings: “Steeple sign” due to subglottic narrowing
  • Management: Nebulized racemic epinephrine

Retropharyngeal abscess:

  • Microbiology: Polymicrobial (streptococcus pyogenes, staphylococcus aureus and anaerobes)
  • Median age: 6 months – 6 years
  • Clinical features: Fever, odonyphagia/dysphagia, drooling, neck stiffness, muffled voice and trismus.
  • X-ray findings: Widened pre-vertebral space
  • Management: Intravenous antibiotics + Surgical drainage, emergency endotracheal intubation as required

Parapharyngeal abscess presents similar to Retropharyngeal abscess and is best diagnosed on CT.

Steeple sign – Croup

Widened prevertebral space-Retropharyngeal abscess

Note:

The most common cause of epiglottitis:
In India - Hemophilus influenza.
Rest of the World - Strep. pneumonia.

Though Nelson mentions that H.influenza is not the most common cause of this condition, the latest edition of O.P Ghai still mentions H.influenza as the most common cause of acute epiglottitis. 
What it means is that, in India, even though cases of H. influenza are coming down due to increased vaccine coverage, still H. influenza remains the leading cause of acute epiglottitis in India.

questions.text: A newborn presents with hypoplasia of the mandibles and zygomatic bones, malformed external ears, and slanted palpebral fissures. An abnormality in the development of which pharyngeal arch is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of Treacher Collins syndrome that results from abnormal development of the 1st pharyngeal arch (mandibular arch). 

First arch syndromes are congenital defects caused due to the failure of the neural crest cells to migrate into the 1st pharyngeal arch. They are:

Treacher Collins syndrome (mandibulofacial dysostosis) - Autosomal dominant genetic disorder characterized by:

  • Craniofacial bone defects - Involves mandible, maxilla, and zygomatic arches, causing micrognathia.
  • Ear defects - Involves the external ear, atresia of auditory canals, and abnormalities of the middle ear ossicles leading to bilateral conductive hearing loss
  • Eye defects - Down-slanting palpebral fissures and lower eyelid colobomas

Pierre Robin sequence (or Robin sequence) - Caused due to genetic defects or due to environmental factors. It can also be seen in oligohydramnios when the chin gets compressed against the chest in utero. 

  • It is characterized by a triad of micrognathia, glossoptosis (posteriorly placed tongue), and cleft palate.
  • The primary defect is poor growth of the mandible (micrognathia). As a consequence of this, the tongue is posteriorly placed (glossoptosis), Additionally, the tongue remains in between the palatal shelves and they fail to fuse (cleft palate)

questions.text: A young infant with cyanotic heart disease presents with the following radiograph. Which of the following is not a component of this patient's disease?
questions.solution:
In a child with cyanotic heart disease and a plain radiograph showing a boot-shaped heart, the likely diagnosis is tetralogy of Fallot (TOF). An atrial septal defect is not a component of TOF.

Tetralogy of Fallot is cyanotic congenital heart disease with four classical anatomical features. These features are:

  • Severe right ventricular outflow obstruction
  • Ventricular septal defect
  • An aorta that overrides the ventricular septal defect
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy

Patients present with symptoms such as cyanosis, dyspnea on exertion, and anoxic spells.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in some congenital heart defects

Boot shaped heart - Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

Egg on side appearance - Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA)

 

Snowman's heart appearance or Figure of 8 appearance - Supracardiac TAPVC

 

Box Shaped Heart - Ebstein's Anomaly

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms is not included in the triad of  Van der Hoeve syndrome?
questions.solution:
Icterus is not included in the triad of Van der Hoeve syndrome

Van der Hoeve Syndrome Triad:

  • Osteogenesis Imperfecta: A genetic disorder characterized by brittle bones that are prone to fractures.
  • Otosclerosis: An abnormal bone growth in the middle ear leading to hearing loss.
  • Blue Sclera: The white part of the eye appears blue or gray due to the thinness of the sclera, revealing the underlying choroidal veins.

Van der Hoeve syndrome primarily involves skeletal and auditory abnormalities, and jaundice is not a characteristic feature.

Icterus may indicate a different underlying pathology, such as liver dysfunction or hemolytic disorders, which should be evaluated separately.

questions.text: A slide of the testis shows features of testicular atrophy with the tubules showing Sertoli cells but no spermatogenesis and an increase in the interstitial Leydig cells. The condition is ___________
questions.solution:
The given histopathological features are strongly suggestive of cryptorchidism.

Cryptorchidism is the failure of the descent of the intra-abdominal testes into the scrotal sac.  It is the most common congenital abnormality of the genitourinary tract. The testes can arrest anywhere during descent, and the most common site is the inguinal region.

Cryptorchidism is histopathologically characterized by the following: 

  1. Testicular atrophy: thickening of the basement membrane, arrested germ cell development, marked hyalinization
  2. Tubules showing Sertoli cells but no spermatogenesis
  3. Increase in the interstitial Leydig cells 
 It is associated with testicular atrophy and dysfunction, which result in sterility. Cryptorchid testes carry a 3–5-fold higher risk for testicular cancer (usually seminoma).

questions.text: A patient presented with multiple, small, pink nodular growths on the temples. A biopsy from the lesion showed the following. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a jigsaw puzzle appearance which is seen in cylindroma (turban tumor/Spiegler’s tumor). 

Cylindroma is a familial autosomal dominant disorder. It is due to the loss of the cylindromatosis gene, CYLD on chromosome 16q12-13. It has also been reported to follow radiotherapy epilation of the scalp. 

The lesions are frequently multiple, smooth, firm, pink to red, and somewhat pedunculated. They are mostly seen on the scalp. Histologically, it contains mosaic‐like masses - a jigsaw appearance. Malignant transformation is very rare.

Surgery is the treatment of choice.

Note: Genetic syndromes associated with adnexal tumors:

  • Germline mutations in CYLD - familial cylindromatosis, familial trichoepithelioma
  • Brooke–Spiegler syndrome - associated with trichoepithelioma, cylindroma, spiradenoma
  • Muir–Torre syndrome - sebaceous adenomas
  • Cowden syndrome - multiple trichilemmomas

questions.text: A farmer from sub-Himalayan belt had a thorn prick injury a year back and developed a warty, verrucous growth at the site of prick. Histopathology of the lesion is given in the image. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of thorn prick injury, warty, verrucous growth and the histopathological image showing medlar bodies suggest chromoblastomycosis.

Chromoblastomycosis, the most common chromomycosis, is more commonly seen in tropical areas among agricultural workers and woodcutters who walk barefoot. Traumatic implantation is the mode of infection.

Patients present with warty cauliflower-like cutaneous nodules on the feet and lower legs. The disease generally remains localised with slow peripheral extension. Lymphatic spread can occur.

Histologically, the lesions are granulomatous, and the dark sclerotic bodies may be seen within leukocytes or giant cells called medlar/copper penny bodies.

Other options:

Option A: Blastomycosis is a fungal infection caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis, typically affecting the lungs, skin, and bones. It presents with flu-like symptoms, skin lesions, or pulmonary disease and is acquired through inhalation of fungal spores from soil.

The image given below shows the skin lesions and microscopy of broad-based budding by Blastomyces dermitidis.

Option B: Pheohyphomycosis is a fungal infection caused by dematiaceous (pigmented) fungi, affecting the skin, sinuses, or brain. It can present as cutaneous nodules, sinusitis, or cerebral abscesses, often in immunocompromised individuals.

Option D: Sporotrichosis is a fungal infection caused by Sporothrix schenckii, typically affecting the skin and lymphatics. It presents as painless nodules that may ulcerate and spread along lymphatic channels, often following trauma involving plants or soil. questions.text: In a normal distribution curve, what is the percentage of the distribution, that falls within two standard deviations of the mean?
questions.solution:
Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within ±2 standard deviations of the mean.

Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within ±1 standard deviations of the mean.

Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within ±3 standard deviations of the mean.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

  • Normal distribution is the most widely used continuous distribution.
  • It is also called bell curve (bell shaped) or Gaussian distribution after a mathematician named Karl Friedrich Gauss.
  • The following is an image of three different types of normal distributions.
  • Normal distributions are defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation.
  • The mean, median and mode are all equal in a normal distribution.
  • All normal distributions are symmetric and have bell-shaped density curves with a single peak.
  • Exactly half of the values are to the left of the centre and the other half to the right.
  • The total area under the curve is 1.
  • The density of a normal distribution is more around the centre and less around the tails.
  • There is no skew in the curve.
  • Looking at the figure below, we can understand the empirical rule of a normal distribution which states that:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 1 SD).
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD).
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD).
  • Many data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution.
  • A standard normal distribution is a normal distribution with a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1.

questions.text: A patient presents with findings as shown in the image below: 1) shows the site of the lesion,  2) has loss of proprioception, vibration, and discriminative touch 3) has loss of pain and temperature beginning one or two segments below the side of the lesion on the contralateral side. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image along with the features above is diagnostic of Brown Sequard syndrome.

Hemisection of the spinal cord causes damage to ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway, ventrolateral spinothalamic tract) and descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways, which is called the Brown-Séquard syndrome.

The part marked as 1 is the site of the lesion, at which hemisection of the cord is seen.

The part marked as 2 is the ipsilateral side of the lesion, which has the following features.

  • Loss of proprioception and vibration
  • Loss of discriminative touch
  • Weakness and spastic type of paralysis in certain muscle groups

The part marked as 3 is the contralateral side of the lesion and exhibits the following features

  • Loss of pain and temperature beginning one or two segments below the side of the lesion

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text: An elderly man is diagnosed with a slow-growing tumor in the deep perineal pouch. Which of the following structures would most likely be affected?
questions.solution:
A tumor in the deep perineal space is most likely to affect the bulbourethral glands as they are present in the deep perineal pouch.

Contents of deep perineal pouch:

  • Membranous urethra
  • Muscles: Sphincter urethrae and deep transverse perineal muscles
  • Nerves: Dorsal nerve of penis and muscular branches of the perineal nerve
  • Vessels: Artery of penis
  • Glands: Bulbourethral glands in males

Contents of superficial perineal pouch: 

  • Corpora cavernosa and corpus spongiosum
  • Three muscles – the ischiocavernosus, bulbospongiosus, and superficial transverse perineal
  • The Bartholin’s glands (greater vestibular glands) in females and the duct of bulbourethral glands in males.
  • Arteries: Branches of the perineal artery (posterior scrotal and transverse perineal arteries) and branches of artery of the penis (artery to the bulb, urethral artery, deep artery of the penis, and dorsal artery of the penis)
  • Nerves: Long perineal nerve, branches of the perineal nerve (posterior scrotal, nerve to bulb and muscular branches)
  • Clitoris in female
  • Urethra in male

questions.text: You are working in a Microbiology lab and have prepared the following culture medium for antibiotic sensitivity testing.  Which of the following methods is used here?
questions.solution:
The given image shows antibiotic sensitivity testing in which lawn culture method is used. 

Methods used in bacterial culture: 

  • Stab culture- It is used for demonstration of gelatin liquefaction and oxygen requirements of bacterium, for maintenance of stock cultures. 
  • Streak culture- It is routinely used for the isolation of bacteria in pure culture from clinical specimens.
  • Stroke culture- It is employed for providing pure growth of bacterium for slide agglutination and other diagnostic tests.
  • Lawn culture/carpet culture- It is used for bacteriophage typing and antibiotic sensitivity testing.
  • Liquid culture- These are preferred for inocula containing antibiotics and other inhibitory substances.
  • Pour plate culture- It gives an estimate of viable bacterial count in a suspension.

questions.text: Following an earthquake, the building codes were changed to earthquake-resistant buildings. Which of the following step of disaster management does this fall under?
questions.solution:
Changing the building codes to earthquake-resistant buildings are part of disaster mitigation.

Disaster mitigation measures aim to reduce the vulnerability of the system. It complements disaster preparedness and response activities and includes measures taken to lessen the likely effects of emergencies. Some of these measures are:

  • Flood mitigation
  • Land-use planning
  • Improved building codes
  • Reduction and protection of vulnerable populations or structures.

Other options:

Option A - Disaster response includes activities such as rescue and first aid, field care, triage and tagging that form a part of the emergency care needed in the first few hours after a disaster.

Option B - Disaster reconstruction is a part of the recovery phase after a disaster.

Option C - Disaster rehabilitation refers to measures that lead to the restoration of pre-disaster conditions. These measures include water supply restoration, food safety, basic sanitation, personal hygiene, and vector control.
