  • At 9-12 months: Head circumference = Chest circumference
  • After 1 year: Head circumference < Chest circumference

Interesting fact!

A boy's height at 2 and half years is half of his adult height and a girl's height at 2 years is half of her adult height.

To roughly predict adult height, use the formula:

  • Adult height = height at 2.5 years for boys (or 2 years for girls) X 2

According to WHO growth charts, the height-for-age for most of the children lies between 70-90 cm during these periods. The double of it, i.e. 140-180 cm is the average height that most of us achieve as adults.

questions.text: A 20 yr old male was brought to casualty in unconscious state after a head injury. On examination, CSF rhinorrhea and Battle sign are noted. Which of the following most likely occured to this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with a battle sign, indicates a skull base fracture associated with bruising over mastoid process. Battle sign and CSF rhinorrhea are features of a middle cranial fossa fracture.

Middle cranial fossa fracture is associated with:

  • CSF otorrhea or rhinorrhea
  • Hemotympanum
  • Ossicular disruption
  • Battle sign: Bruising behind the ear
  • 7th and 8th cranial nerve palsies

CSF rhinorrhea or otorrhea: Double target sign, a double-ring pattern described with CSF-containing bloody fluid from the ear or nose, when dripped onto paper or linen.

Double target sign is seen patients with CSF rhinorrhea. The nasal discharge in a patient with CSF rhinorrhea after head trauma is mixed with blood. When this discharge is collected on a filter paper, it shows a double target sign with a central red spot and a peripheral lighter halo as seen in the image below. 

The image below shows the 'battle' sign.

Anterior cranial fossa fracture is associated with:

  • Subconjunctival hematoma
  • CSF rhinorrhea
  • Carotico-cavernous fistula
  • Periorbital hematoma or “Raccoon eyes”

Periorbital ecchymosis (raccoon eyes): Pooling of blood surrounding the eyes, associated with fractures of the anterior cranial fossa (given below). 

Other options:

Option A: Duret hemorrhages are delayed, secondary brainstem hemorrhages. They occur in craniocerebral trauma victims with rapidly evolving descending transtentorial herniation. They are typically located in the ventral and paramedian aspects of the upper brainstem.

Option B: Kernohan phenomenon is a radiological finding resulting from extensive midline shift due to mass effect, resulting in indentation in the contralateral cerebral crus by the tentorium cerebelli. 

Option D: An epidural hematoma forms between the skull and the dura mater, which also occurs after a head injury, but presents with a lucid interval.

  • Bilateral periorbital haematoma (raccoon eyes)
  • Battle’s sign (bruising over mastoid)
  • CSF rhinorrhoea or otorrhoea
  • Haemotympanum or bleeding from ear

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient with early morning stiffness and chronic pain over small joints was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis. She has been on drugs for the past few years, without any improvement. Now, it has been decided to start her on biological agents. Which of the following will not be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
IL-17A antagonist is not used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis.

IL-17A antagonists (secukinumab, ixekizumab) can be used in the treatment of moderate to severe plaque or scalp psoriasis.

All the other 3 are biological Disease Modifying Anti-Rheumatoid Drugs (DMARDs) used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. All biological DMARDs downregulate the immune system and can lead to adverse effects like opportunistic infections and the flaring of latent TB.

Other options:

Option B: IL-1 receptor antagonist - anakinra

Option C: IL-6 receptor antagonist - tocilizumab and sarilumab

Option D: TNF α antagonist - adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, etc.,

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

NSAIDs - Analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive agents for the management of uncontrollable symptoms and useful in an acute flare.

Glucocorticoids - Used during an acute flare for rapid disease control and as initial therapy before the onset of the effect of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed to control disease in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone- oral 
  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     
DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs

Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX): It is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine: It used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine: A salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide: A pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

 

Biologicals:

  • TNF-α antagonists: Used in combination with MTX. Has a risk of serious bacterial infections, opportunistic fungal infection & reactivation of latent TB. The TNF-α inhibitors are adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, infliximab, and certolizumab.
  • Abatacept: A T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab: An anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.
  • Anakinra: An IL-1 receptor antagonist. It should not be combined with an anti-TNF alpha.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists: Tocilizumab and sarilumab are used as monotherapy or combination therapy in moderate to severe disease.  

 

Small molecules: Janus kinase inhibitors: Tofacitinib, barcitinib, and upadacitinib are used as monotherapy or combination therapy.

questions.text: During your rotation in the postnatal ward, a concerned mother asks you the period by which her newborn infant should have passed urine. The baby was delivered at term gestation and her pregnancy was uneventful. You reassure her by saying that her child should urinate at least once within a period of ______
questions.solution:
The child should urinate at least once within a period of 24 hours after birth.

It is estimated that almost all healthy premature, term, and post-term infants pass urine within the first 24 hours after birth. Failure to pass urine within this period warrants further evaluation.

Anuria is defined as an absence of urine output 48 hours after birth and is a feature of underlying renal failure or acute kidney injury.

  • Low birth weight infants
  • Infants post congenital heart surgery
  • Infants on extracorporeal membrane oxygenation

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of the optic disc in glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Roenne's nasal step is not a feature of the optic disc in glaucoma.

Roenne's nasal step is a visual field defect. It is the result of two arcuate scotomas running in different arcs and meeting at the horizontal meridian. This forms a right-angled defect in the nasal side of the visual field. 

Early glaucomatous changes of the optic disc include an increase in cup-disc ratio (C/D ratio) to more than 0.4, splinter hemorrhages near the optic disc margin, and atrophy of the retinal nerve fiber layer.

Advanced glaucomatous changes of the optic disc include a marked increase in C/D ratio (0.7 or more), thinning of the neuroretinal rim, nasal shifting of the retinal vessels or bayonetting, and pulsations of retinal arterioles at the disc margin.

If the damage progresses, all neural tissue is destroyed and the optic nerve appears white and deeply excavated.

questions.text: The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare is planning strategies to completely prevent the emission of nitrogen dioxide and carbon monoxide.  Which level of prevention does this fall under?
questions.solution:
Strategies to completely prevent the emission of nitrogen dioxide and sulfur dioxide fall under the primordial level of prevention. 

The primordial level of prevention involves the prevention of the emergence or development of risk factors in countries or population groups in which they have not yet appeared.

Primordial prevention consists of risk factor reduction targeted towards an entire population through a focus on social and environmental conditions. Measures taken for this level of prevention are typically promoted through laws and national policies. The main intervention in primordial prevention is individual and mass education.

Examples of the concerns addressed at this level include adult health problems, like obesity and hypertension, that have an early onset due to lifestyle factors, like smoking, poor eating patterns, and lack of physical exercise; preventive measures are directed at discouraging these practices from early childhood.

Other options:

Option A: Secondary prevention includes early disease detection and targets healthy-looking individuals with subclinical forms of the disease. Secondary prevention is defined by intervention that halts the progress of the disease at its incipient stage and prevents complications.

Screening tests and early diagnosis are the specific interventional strategies used in the secondary level of prevention, and they help arrest the disease process. It is an imperfect tool in the control of the transmission of disease. It is often more expensive and less effective than primary prevention. A Papanicolaou (Pap) smear is an example of secondary prevention aimed to diagnose cervical cancer in its subclinical state before progression.

Option C: Tertiary prevention includes all rehabilitation measures available to reduce or limit impairments and disabilities and to minimize suffering caused by any stage of the disease. This also promotes the patient's adjustment to irremediable conditions. Tertiary prevention extends the concepts of prevention by rehabilitation.

Examples include occupational and physical therapy in burns patients and cardiac rehabilitation in post-myocardial infarction patients.

Option D: Primary prevention is defined as an action taken prior to the onset of disease, which removes the possibility that a disease will ever occur. Primary prevention is obtained by measures promoting general health and well-being and the quality of life of people by specific protective measures. This helps in the modification of risk factors of a  disease. They include two strategies:

  • Population (mass) strategy where the target group is the whole population
  • A high-risk strategy where the target group is limited to the people who are most at risk of developing a particular disease

Examples are sanitation, immunization, and the protection of food.

questions.text: What would be the primary aim of surgery in a patient presenting with the following otoscopic finding?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a white mass located in the anterosuperior quadrant behind the intact eardrum suggestive of cholesteatoma. The primary aim is to clear the disease and render the ear safe. The second priority is to preserve or reconstruct the hearing, but never at the cost of the primary aim.

The primary goal of surgery in cholesteatoma cases is to clear the disease completely, eliminating the mass and preventing further complications.
Cholesteatoma can erode bone and cause damage to structures in the middle ear, making clearance crucial for patient safety.

Secondary Priorities:

  • Hearing Restoration: While preserving or reconstructing hearing is important, it is considered a secondary priority to clearing the disease.
  • Perforation Closure: Closing the perforation is also important but is not the primary aim; it is often addressed after clearing the disease.

Other Options:

  • While hearing restoration is a secondary goal, it should not compromise the primary aim of clearing the disease.
  • Reconstruction is a part of the overall surgical approach, especially if there is damage, but it serves the broader goal of disease clearance.
  • Closing the perforation is important, but it is secondary to the primary aim of disease clearance in cholesteatoma cases.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient presents with recent onset of photosensitivity and the development of vesicles and bullae on the sun-exposed areas of his skin. A urine analysis showed the presence of elevated levels of uroporphyrin I. Investigations revealed a deficiency in the enzyme uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT).

Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT) is the most common type of porphyria and presents with cutaneous and hepatic features. It is caused due to a deficiency in the enzyme uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase, which converts uroporphyrinogen III to coproporphyrinogen III.

The accumulated porphyrins are transported to the skin and act as photosensitizers. Hence, the patients usually present with skin friability, milia, and bullae on the sun-exposed skin of the dorsal aspect of the hands, forearms, face, legs, and feet. Hypertrichosis, mottled pigmentary change, and scleroderma-like induration are associated features.

The porphyrins accumulate in the liver and are excreted in urine and bile. Hepatic iron stores are increased as PCT is an iron-related disorder. Liver dysfunction is common in these patients and the risk of developing hepatocellular carcinoma is increased. 

Diagnosis is made by the classical clinical feature of photosensitivity with elevated urine, stool, and plasma uroporphyrin with normal red cell uroporphyrin.

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria
  • Erythropoietic porphyria

Hepatic porphyria is caused due to enzyme deficiency early in the pathway of heme synthesis. There is an accumulation of ALA and PBG. The patient principally presents with neurovisceral symptoms.

Erythropoietic porphyria is caused due to enzyme deficiency late in the pathway of heme synthesis. There is an accumulation of porphyrins which leads to cutaneous photosensitivity.

questions.text: All of the following are associated adverse effects of captopril except:
questions.solution:
Hypokalemia is not an adverse effect of ACE(angiotensin converting enzyme) inhibitor.

ACE inhibitors, like captopril, and lisinopril, are associated with the development of

  • Hyperkalemia (not hypokalemia)
  • Hypotension
  • Cough
  • Dysgeusia
  • Skin rash
  • Neutropenia and

Hyperkalemia occurs due to the inhibition of angiotensin II-mediated aldosterone secretion. Decreased aldosterone levels result in decreased tubular excretion of potassium in the kidneys leading to hyperkalemia.

The adverse effects of ACE inhibitors are:

Hyperkalemia - Hyperkalemia occurs due to the inhibition of angiotensin II-mediated aldosterone secretion. Decreased aldosterone levels result in decreased tubular excretion of potassium in the kidneys leading to hyperkalemia.

Hypotension - A sudden fall in blood pressure can occur following the first dose of ACE inhibitors.

Cough - It can produce a bothersome dry cough due to the accumulation of bradykinin, substance P, or prostaglandins in the lungs. The cough usually disappears within 4 days of the stoppage of the drug. In very few patients(0.1%-0.5%), ACE inhibitors cause rapid swelling in the nose, throat, mouth, glottis, larynx, lips, or tongue. Once the drug is stopped symptoms improve drastically over hours. Angioedema of the intestine can occur very rarely.

Angioedema - ACE inhibitor-associated angioedema is a class effect, and patients who develop this adverse event should not be prescribed any other drugs within the ACE inhibitor class.

Teratogenicity - ACE inhibitors cause reduced perfusion and oligohydramnios leading to fetal growth retardation, calvarium maldevelopment, hypoplasia of lungs and kidneys, and limb contractures.

Dysgeusia (alteration in or loss of taste)

Acute renal failure can occur with ACE inhibitors in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis, stenosis of the artery to a single remaining kidney, heart failure, or volume depletion due to diarrhea or diuretics.

Skin rash

Extremely rare but reversible side effects include neutropenia, glycosuria in the absence of hyperglycemia, anemia, and hepatotoxicity.

questions.text: A 55 year old postmenopausal woman came with complaints of irregular bleeding, breast tenderness, and abdominal pain. Abdomino-pelvic ultrasound revealed an adnexal mass. A biopsy from the mass revealed the following picture. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with biopsy showing gland-like structures, called Call–Exner bodies are suggestive of granulosa cell tumor.

Granulosa cell tumors are ovarian sex-cord stromal tumors made up of cells closely resembling the granulosa cells of the ovarian follicle. The majority of the time it is seen in post-menopausal women. 

These tumors are usually unilateral. In adult women, they may be associated with proliferative breast disease, postmenopausal irregular bleeding, breast tenderness, endometrial hyperplasia, and endometrial carcinoma. The presence of this tumor in prepubertal girls may lead to precocious puberty. Occasionally, granulosa cell tumors produce androgens, masculinizing the patient

The cut section is soft and has a yellowish reticular or trabecular appearance with interstitial hemorrhage. On microscopy, Call- Exner bodies are seen which are small, distinctive, glandlike structures filled with an acidophilic material that resemble immature follicles.

Other options:

Option B: A yolk sac tumor/endodermal sinus tumor is an aggressive malignant germ cell tumor of the ovaries. Most of the yolk sac tumors have Schiller-Duval bodies and they are pathognomonic.

Option C: Krukenberg tumor is the carcinoma of the stomach that metastasize to the ovary. It is characterized by mucin-producing signet ring cells. 

Option D: Seminoma is the most common type of germ-cell tumor. The histological image shows sheets of uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and a central nucleus, with a prominent nucleolus giving a fried-egg.

questions.text: The blood-testis barrier is formed by______

choices.text: Tight junctions between adjacent leydig cells
Tight junctions between adjacent sertoli cells

questions.solution:
The blood-testis barrier is formed by the tight junctions between adjacent Sertoli cells.

This Sertoli-Sertoli cell tight junctions divide the seminiferous epithelium into 2 compartments:

  • Basal compartment - contains the spermatogonia and early-stage primary spermatocytes.
  • Adluminal compartment - contains later-stage primary spermatocytes and all subsequent stages of sperm cells.

It imparts a selective permeability, allowing few substances such as testosterone to cross and preventing noxious substances that might damage the developing sperm. It also protects sperm from antibodies by creating a specialized, immunologically safe microenvironment for developing sperm.

questions.text: A mother of five, brings her youngest child, an 18-month-old girl, for evaluation. The child appears very thin with minimal fat distribution. There is severe wasting of the shoulders, arms, buttocks, and thighs as shown in the below image. The middle-upper arm circumference is less than 11.5cm. The child is alert and irritable. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The alert and irritable child with severe fat wasting in the areas of the shoulders, arms, buttocks, and thighs is likely to have marasmus. 

Marasmus is a type of severe protein-energy malnutrition which occurs due to insufficient calorie intake. It is characterized by severe wasting of fat and muscles. The child appears to be very thin,  having a 'skin and bones' appearance with no fat. 

The loss of buccal fat leads to the 'monkey facies' or 'old man face' due to its aged and wrinkled appearance. 'Baggy pants appearance' is due to the presence of loose skin in the buttocks that hangs low. 

Other features that may be present are hypotension, hypothermia, and bradycardia as well as micronutrient deficiencies. 

Diagnosis of severe acute malnutrition is made with the help of anthropometry.

  • Weight for height is below -3 standard deviations for the mean on the World Health Organization (WHO) chart  or,
  • Presence of bipedal edema or,
  • Middle-upper arm circumference (MUAC) is less than 115mm (in the red zone of the tape as shown below). 

 

The children should be assessed for the following: 

  • Severe edema 
  • Low appetite (failed appetite test) 
  • Medical complications 
  • One or more danger sign

If any of the above are present, the child should be treated as a case of complicated severe acute malnutrition and should have inpatient management. Uncomplicated cases can have supervised home management. 

The WHO recommends testing hemoglobin, total blood count, peripheral blood smear, blood glucose, serum albumin, electrolytes, stool microscopy with culture, parasitic evaluation, retroviral testing, and urine microscopy with culture. 

Other options: 

Option A - Kwashiorkor is another type of protein-energy malnutrition that is characterized mainly by pitting edema starting in the legs and feet that spread to the hands and face. They also show skin changes characterized by increased pigmentation and desquamation. They do not show signs of hunger and are difficult to feed. The weight for height may be normal. The following image shows the edema and the skin changes seen in Kwashiorkor.

 

Option C - Chronic pancreatitis can mimic protein-energy malnutrition. It can occur due to cystic fibrosis and obstruction of the pancreatic ducts due to roundworms. This would present with prolonged abdominal pain, weight loss, and steatorrhea. 

Option D - Marasmic kwashiorkor is a mixed form of malnutrition that presents with features of both marasmus and kwashiorkor. There will be edema, and growth stunting with less severe hair and skin changes of kwashiorkor.

questions.text: A 68-year-old  female patient, who is a known case of poorly controlled diabetes presents to the clinic with complaints of hazy vision. Which of the following types of cataracts can be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The typical appearance of a diabetic cataract is a snowflake cataract.

Increased levels of blood glucose also lead to high levels of glucose in the aqueous humor. questions.text: A middle-aged female comes to the clinic for follow-up three weeks after left parotidectomy. She complains of flushing, sweating, and burning sensation on the left side of her face every time she sits down to have a meal. The postganglionic parasympathetic nerve fibers of which of the following nerves is the likely culprit for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
The symptom complex in this patient along with a history of recent parotid surgery is indicative of Frey's syndrome in which the auriculotemporal nerve marked as "D" is involved.

Frey’s syndrome/Gustatory sweating (auriculotemporal syndrome)

  • Commonly develops after parotid surgery or other trauma that results in the opening of the parotid capsule.
  • It results from damage to the autonomic innervation of the salivary gland. There is a regeneration of the parasympathetic nerve fibres that stimulate the sweat glands of the overlying skin in response to salivary stimulation or mastication. 
  • It is thought to reflect abnormal innervation of sweat glands on the face by regrowing parasympathetic secretomotor axons that would previously have innervated the parotid gland
  • Clinical features:
    • Sweating, warmth, and erythema over the region of surgical excision of the parotid gland. This is due to the autonomic stimulation of salivation by the smell/taste of food.
  • Diagnosis:
    • The starch iodine will aid in diagnosis. The affected area painted with iodine will turn blue on exposure to sweat.
  • Management:
    • Antiperspirants with aluminium chloride
    • Subcutaneous infiltration of purified botulinum toxin into the affected area
    • Denervation by a tympanic neurectomy or auriculotemporal nerve avulsion has been advocated but is often not curative

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy was seen by the optometrist for complaints of blurred vision.  While examining for refractive error, he noticed that the child's corneas were unusually small for his age and referred him for further evaluation. Below what horizontal diameter can a diagnosis of microcornea be made in this child?
questions.solution:
To make a diagnosis of microcornea, in this child, the diameter of the cornea should be less than 10 mm.

Micro-cornea

  • Horizontal corneal diameter is 10 mm or less (over 2 years of age) or less than 9 mm (in the newborn).
  • There may be hypermetropia and a shallow anterior chamber but other dimensions are normal.

Megalocornea

  • Horizontal corneal diameter is 12 mm or more (up to 2 years of age) or 13 mm or more (if age >2 years)
  • There is typically high myopia and astigmatism, but normal corrected visual acuity.
  • Usually X-linked recessive; 90% of affected individuals are male.

Cornea plana

  • The cornea is flatter than normal, i.e., the radius of curvature is larger.
  • There is a corresponding reduction in refractive power, resulting in high hypermetropia.

Keratectasia

  • It is characterized by a protuberance between the eyelids caused by a severely opacified, and sometimes vascularized, cornea.
  • It is often associated with raised intraocular pressure as well as intrauterine keratitis.
  • Usually unilateral

Microphthalmos

  • Microphthalmia is a condition in which the entire eye is small, with an axial length at least two standard deviations below the mean for age.
  • It may or may not be associated with ocular dysgenesis.

Nanophthalmos

  • In nanophthalmos (simple microphthalmos), the entire eye is small, but is structurally normal; 
  • It is usually associated with hypermetropia and strabismus

Anophthalmos: Anophthalmos (anophthalmia) refers to the complete absence of any visible globe structure.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought with bilateral cheek swelling,  pain, tenderness, and fever for the last two days. Which of the following is not a complication of this infection?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a parotid swelling with fever is suggestive of mumps infection. Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is not a complication of this disease. SSPE is caused by a measles infection.

Mumps is an infection caused by the mumps virus, a paramyxovirus. It causes non-suppurative inflammation and growth of the parotid glands. 

The mode of infection is inhalation or contact through the conjunctiva. The virus infects the respiratory tract leading to replication and dissemination through the cervical lymph nodes and bloodstream. The incubation period is about 12-25 days

Mumps infection usually presents with unilateral or bilateral parotid swelling. Unilateral disease usually progresses to bilateral involvement. It is accompanied by fever, local pain and tenderness but the skin over the gland is not warm or erythematous. It is usually self-limiting and resolves within a week. However, the involvement of other organs is detrimental and leads to severe complications.

Complications of mumps infection: 

  1. Epidymo-orchitis (Option A) is characterized by swollen, intensely painful testicles. This is usually associated with fever and chills. This may lead to testicular atrophy and decreased sperm counts. 
  2. Meningoencephalitis (Option B) or meningitis can occur. This is usually aseptic and is characterized by pleocytosis on cerebrospinal fluid examination. This may lead to deafness as a complication. 
  3. Acute pancreatitis (Option C) can occur. This generally resolves with conservative treatment. 
  4. Arthritis may occur with monoarticular or polyarticular involvement. 
  5. Myocardial involvement: Transient ECG changes are seen. Rapidly progressive myocarditis can occur.

A typical case of mumps needs no laboratory confirmation, but in atypical cases and complications, diagnosis may be established by virus isolation and serological tests.

Prophylaxis of mumps is done through the administration of an effective live virus vaccine containing the Jeryl-Lynn strain of the virus. The vaccine is given as a single subcutaneous injection, alone or in combination with the measles and rubella vaccines (Measles - Mumps - Rubella vaccine: MMR vaccine)

They are made up of cytokeratin 8 and cytokeratin 18. They have a twisted rope-like appearance. On trichrome stain, they appear green/dark brown. They are seen in:

  • Wilson's disease

  • Primary biliary cholangitis (formerly called primary biliary cirrhosis)

questions.text: A 2-day-old neonate was admitted to the NICU after he was observed to have movements as shown in the clip. His APGAR scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. His blood sugar was within the normal range in the first 24 hours. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clip depicts neonatal seizure of focal clonic type.

A focal clonic seizure is characterized by multiple, repetitive, rhythmic contractions of muscle groups of the limbs, face, or trunk, and-

  • Maybe unifocal or multifocal
  • May occur synchronously or asynchronously in muscle groups on one side of the body
  • May occur simultaneously but asynchronously on both sides
  • It cannot be suppressed by restraint

A focal tonic seizure is characterized by sustained posturing of single limbs, sustained asymmetrical posturing of the trunk, sustained eye deviation, cannot be provoked by stimulation or suppressed by restraint.

Spasms are sudden generalized jerks lasting 1-2 sec and are usually associated with a single, very brief, generalized discharge. They may be flexor, extensor, or mixed extensor/flexor and can occur in clusters. It cannot be provoked by stimulation or suppressed by restraint.

Subtle seizures include transient eye deviations, nystagmus, blinking, mouthing, abnormal extremity movements (rowing, swimming, cycling, pedaling), fluctuations in heart rate, hypertension episodes, and apnea. They are more common in premature than in term babies.

WHO recommendations:

  • Clinically apparent seizures in the neonate should be treated if they last >3 minutes or are brief serial seizures.
  • If electroencephalography (EEG) is possible, all electrical seizures should also be treated, even in the absence of clinically apparent conditions.
  • In all neonates with seizures, hypoglycemia, CNS infection, and hypocalcemia should be ruled out before anti-epileptic drug treatment.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency department with multiple fractures of the face and skull, following a road traffic accident. CT scan showed an intact eyeball with normal intraocular pressure. When light is shone into the right eye, both pupils constrict, but neither pupil constricts when light is shone into the left eye. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the presence of constriction in both pupils on shining light in the right eye, and the absence of constriction in both pupils on shining light in the left eye is highly suggestive of left optic nerve transection.

In the pupillary light reflex pathway, the afferent is the optic nerve (CN II) and the efferent is the oculomotor nerve (CN III). The afferent limb consists of the retina, the optic nerve, and the pretectal nucleus of the midbrain at the level of the superior colliculus. The pretectal nucleus projects crossed and non-crossed fibres to the ipsilateral and contralateral Edinger-Westphal nuclei. This connection forms the basis of the consensual light reflex.

Each Edinger-Westphal nucleus gives rise to preganglionic parasympathetic fibres that emerge with CN III to synapse with postganglionic parasympathetic neurons of the ciliary ganglion to innervate the ciliary sphincter.

In left optic nerve injury (e.g., left optic nerve CN II cut somewhere between the retina and the optic chiasm, thus damaging the left afferent limb, leaving the rest of the bilateral pupillary light reflex pathway intact) the following features are seen:

  • Left direct and right consensual reflexes are lost as afferent signals from the left eye cannot pass through the severed left optic nerve to reach the left and right intact efferent limbs respectively.
  • Right direct and left consensual reflexes are intact as right optic, right oculomotor and left oculomotor nerves are intact.

questions.text: A newborn presents to the outpatient department with a history of noisy breathing. Upon performing direct laryngoscopy, specific findings are observed. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the stridor in this infant?

choices.text: Increases in prone position and subsides on crying
Subsides on prone position and increases with crying
Subsides both on crying and prone position
Increases with both prone position and crying

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the laryngoscopy image showing omega-shaped epiglottis is suggestive of laryngomalacia. Inspiratory stridor is seen in laryngomalacia.

Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital cause of stridor. It is characterized by excessive flaccidity of the supraglottic larynx which is sucked in during inspiration. This results in inspiratory stridor, a feature typical of laryngomalacia.

It presents just after birth and subsides by 2 years of age. Stridor is increased on crying but improves (decreases) in the prone position, and worsens during feeding or crying. The cry is normal.

Direct laryngoscopy shows an elongated epiglottis that is curled upon itself, making it appear omega (Ω)-shaped. Other features include floppy aryepiglottic folds and prominent arytenoids.

Stridor is noisy respiration produced by turbulent airflow through narrowed air passages. Stridor may be heard during inspiration, expiration or both

  • Inspiratory stridor- e.g., laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.
  • Expiratory stridor- e.g. bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.
  • Biphasic stridor- e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.

Treatment of Laryngomalacia:

  • Mostly, it self corrects by 2 years of age.
  • Tracheostomy may be required for some cases of severe respiratory obstruction.
  • Supraglottoplasty is required in cases of severe laryngomalacia.

questions.text: A 65-year-old lady presents to the ophthalmology OPD with the finding as shown below. She is diagnosed with a right-sided senile cataract. Identify the stage.
questions.solution:

questions.text: A 36-year-old man is diagnosed with cholera. Which of the following drug would you prescribe to his family members to prevent the spread of the disease?
questions.solution:
Tetracycline is the drug of choice for chemoprophylaxis of cholera.

It should be given for:

  • Adults - a 3-day period in a twice-daily dose of 500mg
  • Children (4-13 years) - 125mg
  • Children (0-3 years) - 50mg

Alternatively, single oral dose of doxycycline may be used for chemoprophylaxis. The dose is 300 mg for adults and 6 mg/kg for children under 15 years.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female came to a dermatology clinic with the complaints of brittle scalp hair and the presence of firmly adherent, black, gritty, hard nodules along the hair shaft. Pruritus is absent. What is the most probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
The presence of brittle scalp hair and firmly adherent, black, gritty, hard nodules along the hair shaft is suggestive of black piedra. The causative agent of this condition is Piedraia hortae.

Piedra is a superficial fungal infection of the hair shaft. 

Management:

Shaving or cutting of the affected hair along with topical antifungals.

questions.text: An elderly male patient with a history of heart failure, currently on a cardiac glycoside, presents to the emergency department with severe vomiting, abdominal pain, visual disturbances, and restlessness. His ECG shows ventricular bigeminy. Which heart failure medication is most likely responsible for this acute presentation?
questions.solution:
In this given clinical scenario, with ECG findings showing ventricular bigeminy, digoxin is the drug that would have likely caused this acute presentation suggestive of digitalis toxicity.  

Digoxin has a very low therapeutic index. Digitalis toxicity can manifests as any type of arrhythmias (atrial tachycardia with AV block is classic) as well as produce severe nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. It also causes visual disturbances such as blurring or yellowing of vision.  

Treatment includes cessation of digoxin administration followed by intravenous potassium in the case of tachyarrhythmia, intravenous lidocaine for ventricular arrhythmia, and intravenous propranolol for supraventricular arrhythmias. Digoxin antibody (Fab fragment) is used in severe cases of digitalis toxicity.

Digoxin is the only cardiac glycoside that is in clinical use. It has a positive inotropic action and helps the failing heart to regain back some of its contractile power and reduces heart rate as well. Digoxin acts by inhibiting the NA+K+ATPase enzyme which causes an increase in intracellular calcium leading to increased contractility and a decrease in peripheral vascular resistance and heart rate. 

The major route of digoxin elimination is by P-glycoprotein (efflux transporter). Drug interactions with amiodarone, quinidine, verapamil, diltiazem, cyclosporine, etc can decrease digoxin clearance and possibly cause digitalis toxicity. 

Other options: 

Option A: Lidocaine is commonly used as a local anesthetic. It has anti-arrhythmic properties and is used to suppress ventricular tachycardia that is caused by digitalis toxicity.

Option C: Valsartan is an angiotensin receptor blocker and is used in heart failure. It acts by arteriolar and venodilatation causing reduction of afterload and preload. It has adverse effects such as headache, dizziness, weakness, and fetopathic potential.

Option D: Levosimendan is an inotropic drug as well as a phosphodiesterase inhibitor. It is primarily used in acute on chronic decompensated heart failure as a short-term therapy. The most common side effect is hypotension.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs when administered would lead to a biphasic reaction on blood pressure?
questions.solution:
Biphasic reaction on blood pressure is seen with the administration of adrenaline. The BP initially rises followed by a fall in BP.

Adrenaline acts on α1, α2, β1, β2, and β3 receptors.

α1 - present in blood vessels - causes vasoconstriction - increases BP.

β2 - present in blood vessels - causes vasodilatation - decreases BP.

At higher concentrations of adrenaline, alpha action predominates and hence a rise in BP is seen. Therefore an increase in BP is seen with IV administration of adrenaline.

Due to rapid metabolism and uptake, the concentration of adrenaline decreases, and the β2 action predominates. Hence a decrease in BP is seen. This is referred to as the biphasic reaction. 

Adrenergic drug

Receptors it acts on

Adrenaline

α1 + α2 +β1 + β2 + weak β3 action

Noradrenaline

α1 +α2 +β1 + β3 but no β2 action

Isoprenaline

β1 + β2 + β3 but no α action

questions.text: A patient undergoing chemotherapy was given an antiemetic, after which he developed symptoms like acute dystonia, bradykinesia, and tremors. Which of the following drugs would have caused these symptoms?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, the patient has developed extrapyramidal adverse effects like acute dystonia, bradykinesia, and tremors. This is likely due to the antagonist action on dopamine receptors by metoclopramide.

Metoclopramide is a prokinetic and antiemetic. It has the following pharmacological actions:

  • Dopamine receptor antagonist 
  • Serotonin (5HT4) receptor agonist 
  • Serotonin (5HT3) antagonist
  • Sensitization of muscarinic receptors on smooth muscle. This results in increased lower esophageal sphincter tone and stimulates gastric antral contractions.

Metoclopramide acts on both the gastrointestinal system and central nervous system. It is used as an upper antiemetic for many types of vomiting, especially migraine, drug-induced, and chemotherapy-induced. It is also used as a prokinetic in gastroparesis to increase gastric emptying.

Adverse effects of metoclopramide are mainly extrapyramidal effects, and these include acute dystonia, Parkinson-like symptoms (tremors, bradykinesia, rigidity), tardive dyskinesia, galactorrhea due to hyperprolactinemia, and methemoglobinemia in neonates.

Extrapyramidal symptoms can be treated by discontinuation of metoclopramide and administration of anticholinergics or antihistaminics.

Other options:

Option A: Ondansetron is a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist. It blocks impulses at the peripheral origin in GIT. It is most commonly indicated for the treatment of postoperative and chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. Headache and dizziness are the common adverse effects.

Option C: Meclizine is a long-acting H1 antihistaminic drug. It is used for seasickness. It is less sedative and less anticholinergic.

Option D: Scopolamine (hyoscine) is a muscarinic antagonist. It blocks neural pathways from the vestibular apparatus in the inner ear to the emetic center in the brainstem. A transdermal patch of scopolamine is used as an antiemetic in motion sickness. Constipation, drowsiness, dry mouth, and blurred vision are the common adverse effects.

questions.text: A surgeon is performing a thyroidectomy for a patient with a multinodular goiter. Damage to which structure is most likely to cause vocal cord paralysis?
questions.solution:
Injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve will cause vocal cord paralysis.

All the intrinsic muscles of the larynx except for the cricothyroid are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve. Cricothyroid is supplied by the external laryngeal nerve which is a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve.

Since most of the laryngeal muscles are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, the most appropriate answer would be recurrent laryngeal nerve.

Other options:

  • External laryngeal nerve: It supplies motor innervation to the cricothyroid muscle, which is responsible for controlling the tension of the vocal cords. Damage to this nerve can cause weakness or paralysis of the cricothyroid muscle, leading to changes in voice quality and pitch. 
  • Internal laryngeal nerve: It provides sensory innervation to the larynx above the vocal cords. Damage to this nerve may result in decreased sensation in the upper part of the larynx
  • Superior laryngeal nerve: Similar to the external laryngeal nerve, damage to the superior laryngeal nerve can affect the function of the cricothyroid muscle.

questions.text: A trumpet player presented with hoarseness of voice, cough, and a reducible neck swelling. The neck swelling increases in size on performing the Valsalva maneuver. Which of the following regions would you expect to find a defect in?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of laryngocele. The defect is present in the saccule, represented by the area marked A in the above diagram.

The structures marked are: 

B. Ventricle

C. Vestibular ligament

D. Vocal ligament

The saccule is a pouch that ascends forwards from the anterior end of the ventricle, between the vestibular fold and thyroid cartilage.

It is conical in shape and contains around 60 and 70 mucous glands, sited in the submucosa.

It is separated from the thyroid cartilage by the thyroepiglotticus muscle which compresses the saccule. On compression, the secretions of the saccule are released into the vocal cords (which lack mucous glands) to lubricate and protect them from desiccation and infection. 

Clinical significance:

Laryngocele is an air-filled cystic swelling due to dilatation of the saccule. It is seen in trumpet players, glass-blowers, or weight lifters due to raised trans-glottic air pressure. It can be internal, external, or combined.

External laryngocele presents as a reducible swelling in the neck which increases in size on coughing or performing Valsalva maneuver.

Internal laryngocele is managed by marsupialization and surgical excision through an external neck incision done for external laryngocele.

questions.text: Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocyte to the plasma by binding to?
questions.solution:
Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocytes into the plasma by binding to ferroportin. 

Hepcidin is released by the liver in response to increases in intrahepatic iron levels. It inhibits iron transfer by binding to ferroportin and causing it to be endocytosed and degraded. As a result, iron becomes trapped within the duodenal cells in the form of mucosal ferritin and is lost in feces when these cells are sloughed off.

Transcription of hepcidin is increased by the following factors:

  • Inflammatory cytokines
  • Iron

Mutation in hepcidin causes Hereditary hemochromatosis. Secondary hemochromatosis can also occur due to the suppression of hepatic hepcidin production in diseases associated with ineffective erythropoiesis, such as β-thalassemia major and myelodysplastic syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following should not be prescribed with theophylline?
questions.solution:
Erythromycin should not be prescribed with theophylline.

Theophylline is mainly metabolized by CYP1A2 in the liver. Erythromycin inhibits CYP1A2 and thereby decreases the clearance of theophylline.

Factors which decrease the clearance of theophylline are:

  • Drugs - erythromycin, cimetidine, ciprofloxacin, allopurinol, fluvoxamine, zileuton, zafirlukast
  • Congestive heart failure
  • Liver disease
  • Pneumonia
  • Viral infection and vaccination
  • High-carbohydrate diet
  • Old age

questions.text: Which of the following is a derived lipid?
questions.solution:
Steroids are derived lipids

Lipids are classified as follows: 

  • Simple lipids: Esters of fatty acids with various alcohols. e.g., fats, oils, and waxes
  • Complex lipids: Esters of fatty acids + alcohol + other groups like phosphate, nitrogenous base, carbohydrate, protein, etc. They can be divided into three groups:
    • Phospholipids: Fatty Acids + alcohol + phosphoric acid and a nitrogenous base. 
    • Glycolipids (glycosphingolipids): Fatty acids + alcohol + carbohydrate
    • Other complex lipids: Lipids such as sulfolipids, amino lipids, and lipoproteins
  • Derived lipids: These are the derivatives of hydrolysis of simple and complex lipids, which possess the characteristics of lipids. Examples: Lipid-soluble vitamins, steroid hormones, ketone bodies, sterols etc.

questions.text: A newborn baby refuses breast milk since the 2nd day of birth but accepts glucose-water, develops vomiting and severe jaundice by the 5th day. Benedict's test was positive for urine and blood glucose was low. The most likely cause is due to the deficiency of
questions.solution:
The above clinical features on ingestion of breastmilk suggest a disorder of galactose metabolism.

Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase deficiency leads to classical galactosemia. It is an autosomal recessive disorder. Clinical features :

  • Accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate in the liver causes liver damage & leads to hepatomegaly, vomiting, convulsions.
  • Accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate depletes the liver of inorganic phosphate leading to diminished ATP synthesis which affects gluconeogenesis resulting in hypoglycemia.
  • Accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate in the nerves causes intellectual disability.
  • Accumulation of galactitol in the lens causes oil-drop cataract.

Urinary reducing sugar (Benedict's test) and Mucic acid test is positive.

Treatment is galactose-free diet.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman was found to have excessive urinary glucose levels. However, her blood glucose levels were normal. Further investigations revealed high levels of L-xylulose in the urine. A genetic defect in which of the following pathways is most likely responsible for this condition?

TCA cycle-tricarboxylic acid cycle

HMP-Hexosemophosphate shunt
questions.solution:
According to the given clinical scenario the genetic defect is in the uronic acid pathway.

High levels of L-xylulose in urine are diagnostic of essential pentosuria, a benign condition caused due to a defect in the uronic acid pathway. Essential pentosuria has no clinical consequences. However, it can give false-positive results when urinary glucose is measured using alkaline copper reagents (Benedict’s test).

Essential pentosuria is due to the lack of enzyme xylulose reductase of the uronic acid pathway. Affected individuals excrete large amounts of L-xylulose in urine. Xylulose being a reducing sugar gives Benedict's test positive. Bial's test is positive as xylulose is a pentose. It is a part of Garrod's tetrad which includes, pentosuria, albinism, cystinuria and alkaptonuria.

Other options :

Option A: The tricarboxylic acid cycle (TCA cycle), also called the citric acid cycle or the Krebs cycle is the final pathway where the oxidative catabolism of carbohydrates, amino acids, and fatty acids occurs with their carbon skeletons being converted to carbon dioxide (CO2). This oxidation provides energy for the production of the majority of ATP. 

Option C: Glycolysis is the main pathway through which cells metabolize glucose and other carbohydrates. It occurs in the cytosol of cells and can function either aerobically or anaerobically depending on the availability of oxygen and the activity of the electron transport chain (and hence of the presence of mitochondria). Erythrocytes, which lack mitochondria, are completely reliant on glucose as their metabolic fuel and metabolize it by anaerobic glycolysis. 

Option D: The pentose phosphate pathway or HMP shunt is an alternative route for the metabolism of glucose. It does not lead to the formation of ATP, but it has two major functions of, formation of NADPH and synthesis of ribose-5-phosphate.

Related Pearl: Essential Pentosuria

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with left knee pain, redness, and swelling for 3 days. Joint aspiration is performed and microscopic findings under polarised light are given in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition disease (CPPD), also known as pseudo-gout and chondrocalcinosis.

The image shows aspirated crystals which are rhomboid, 0.5 to 5 μm in the greatest dimension, and positively birefringent (yellow). 

It usually occurs in individuals older than 50 years of age and becomes more common with old age.

CPPD is classified into sporadic (idiopathic), hereditary, and secondary types. It is caused by germline mutations in the pyrophosphate transport channel. The secondary form is associated with

  • Previous joint damage
  • Hyperparathyroidism
  • Hemochromatosis
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Ochronosis
  • Diabetes 

Inflammation is usually milder than in gout. CPPD may produce acute, subacute, or chronic arthritis that can be confused with osteoarthritis or rheumatoid arthritis. The joint involvement may be monoarticular or polyarticular; the knees, followed by the wrists, elbows, shoulders, and ankles, are most commonly affected.

questions.text: A screening test gave positive results in 60% of the diseased individuals and 20% of the healthy individuals. Calculate the specificity for this test.
questions.solution:
The specificity of a test from the given information can be calculated as 0.8.

60% of individuals having the disease came out to be positive. So for 100 diseased individuals, 60 are True positives and 40 are False negatives.

20% of the individuals not having the disease came out to be positive. so for 100 healthy individuals, 20 are False positives and 80 are true negatives.

The specificity of a test is given by those who are healthy(do not have the disease) and test negative (true negatives) out of the total healthy population. So the specificity = TN divided by TN+FP, i.e 80/100= 0.8

The sensitivity of a test is given by those who have the disease and test positive (true positives) out of the total diseased population. Here Sensitivity= TP/TP+FN = 60/100=0.6

The test's positive predictive value is given by those who have the disease and test positive (true positives) out of the total positive population. Here PPV= TP/TP+FP = 60/80=0.75

The negative predictive value of the test is given by those who do not have the disease and test negative (true negatives) out of the total negative population. NPV here= TN/TN+FN = 80/120=0.67

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy comes with complaints of right ear pain, difficulty in opening the mouth, painful swallowing, and fever. The oral cavity examination reveals the following. The type of speech that would be seen in this patient is?
questions.solution:
The image shows quinsy also known as a peritonsillar abscess. Muffled and thick speech, often called “hot potato voice” is seen in peritonsillar abscess or quinsy. 

Quinsy:

Quinsy is the collection of pus between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx.

Clinical features: 

  • Sore throat/ Dysphagia 
  • Drooling of saliva 
  • Trismus 
  • Ipsilateral otalgia 
  • Fever 

Management of quinsy

  • Hospitalization
  • Intravenous fluids to combat dehydration
  • Antibiotics - Suitable antibiotics in large  i.v. doses to cover aerobes and anaerobes;
  • Analgesics like paracetamol are given for pain relief
  • Oral hygiene should be maintained by hydrogen peroxide or saline mouthwashes.
  • Drainage by needle aspiration, incision, and drainage or tonsillectomy.
  • Incision and drainage of the abscess: A peritonsillar abscess is opened at the point of the maximum bulge above the upper pole of the tonsil or just lateral to the point of junction of the anterior pillar with a line drawn through the base of the uvula.

Other options:

Option A - Staccato voice or scanning speech is a broken speech seen in cerebellar lesions as well as multiple sclerosis.

Option B - Rhinolalia aperta causes a hypernasal voice.

Option D - Rhinolalia clausa/ hyponasal voice can be seen in adenoid hypertrophy.

questions.text:
A young man presents to the ER with complaints of sudden onset nausea, vomiting, and four episodes of passing loose stools. He gives a history of having food from a nearby bakery three hours ago. What is the mechanism of action of the organism most likely implicated here?

cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP)
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient is most likely suffering from gastroenteritis caused by Staphylococcus aureus which acts via preformed Type A enterotoxin.

Staphylococcus causes nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea 2-6 hrs after the consumption of contaminated food. The common sources of infection are foods that are not cooked after handling. These include sliced meats, puddings, pastries, and sandwiches. Patients present with nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, and diarrhea. 

Gastroenteritis is caused by enterotoxin produced by S. aureus. It is a preformed toxin that is relatively heat stable while most of the other exotoxins are heat-labile. It stimulates the vagus nerve and vomiting center of the brain and also stimulates intestinal peristaltic activity. Eight antigenic types of enterotoxin are currently known of which Type  A toxin is responsible for most cases.

Other options:

Option A: The cholera enterotoxin of Vibrio cholerae binds to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on the surface of jejunal epithelial cells. It then causes the accumulation of cAMP. A clinical vignette of sudden onset colorless rice watery, stools having an inoffensive sweetish odor is indicative of cholera.

Option B: The enterotoxin of Bacillus cereus involves stimulation of the cAMP system. It may also cause food poisoning independent of the cAMP system. Food poisoning after consumption of fried rice or Chinese street food is suggestive of B. cereus. 

Option C: Shiga toxin acts by inactivating the 60s ribosomal subunit thereby inhibiting protein synthesis. Shigella dysenteriae causes acute onset of symptoms(fever, abdominal cramps) with dysentery and tenesmus.

questions.text: You are counseling a diabetic patient to consume foods with a low glycemic index. Which of the following food items would you advise this patient to eat?
questions.solution:
The patient should be advised to eat whole grains since it has low glycemic index (GI).

GI is a number representing the relative ability of a carbohydrate food to increase the level of glucose in the blood. It is calculated by comparing the test carbohydrate to the standard (glucose or white bread). This measure has practical use in the management of diabetes and obesity.

  • Low GI foods – most fruits and vegetables, whole grains, pasta foods, beans, and lentils
  • Moderate GI foods – sucrose, basmati rice, and brown rice
  • High GI foods – corn flakes, baked potatoes, white bread, potatoes, watermelon and sweet corn, candies and syrupy foods

questions.text: A pressure-volume diagram of the left ventricle is given below. Calculate the stroke volume considering the heart rate as 65 beats per minute.
questions.solution:
The stroke volume of this pressure-volume diagram is 70 mL.

The points in the graph indicate the following events of the cardiac cycle:

  • Point 1: Opening of the mitral valve. The corresponding reading on the graph denotes end-systolic volume (ESV).
  • Point 2: Closing of the mitral valve. The corresponding reading on the graph denotes end-diastolic volume (EDV).
  • Point 3: Opening of the aortic valve.
  • Point 4: Closing of the aortic valve.

Stroke volume is the amount of blood that the heart pumps out with each beat. It is about 70 mL from each ventricle in resting conditions.

In a pressure-volume diagram, stroke volume (SV) can be calculated using the values of ESV (50 mL) and EDV (120 mL):

Stroke volume = End diastolic volume – End systolic volume

Therefore, SV = 120 - 50 = 70 mL.

Cardiac output can be calculated from the given data using the formula:  Cardiac output = Stroke volume x heart rate

Therefore, in this case, cardiac output = 70 x 65 = 4550 mL.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic presented with severe pain in ear and otorrhoea not responding to antibiotics. Facial nerve palsy is noted. On examination, granulation tissue is seen in the external auditory canal. What is the most common organism responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Elderly diabetic with severe otalgia, otorrhoea, granulation tissue in the external auditory canal and facial nerve palsy indicates malignant otitis externa. The most common causative agent remains Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

Malignant (necrotizing) otitis externa is associated with Pseudomonas infection in elderly diabetics and those on immunosuppressive drugs. It is termed malignant, though being an infection due to the high mortality rate and poor response to treatment.

Patients present with excruciating pain, profuse discharge & granulations on the floor of EAC. Necrosis of bone aids in the spread of infection. Facial paralysis is common.  Infection may spread to the skull base and jugular foramen causing multiple cranial nerve palsies.

Gallium-67 is more useful in the diagnosis and follow-up of the patient. Technetium 99 bone scan reveals bone infection, but the test remains positive for a year or so and cannot be used to monitor the disease. 

Treatment includes:

  • Diabetic control.
  • Ear toileting
  • Antibiotic treatment against the causative organism (P. aeruginosa) for 6–8 weeks or more.
Antibiotics found effective are:
  • Gentamicin combined with ticarcillin (intravenous).
  • Third-generation cephalosporins combined with an aminoglycoside (intravenous).
  • Quinolones combined with rifampin (oral). 
If the patient is not responsive, culture and sensitivity of ear discharge should be done. Prolonged antibiotic treatment has replaced radical surgery and resections done earlier for this condition.
